Dr Binita Kane is a newly appointed consultant respiratory physician at University Hospital of South Manchester. She has a role that is split 50:50 between direct clinical care and clinical leadership. She graduated from the University of Manchester and has a PhD in airways inflammation.

After completing her PhD in 2008, she began working as a specialist registrar in respiratory medicine. She was recruited onto the Medical Leadership programme by Health Education North West in 2013 and completed a Masters in health care leadership in November 2015.

She currently works within an academic department providing tertiary services for people with severe asthma. As a trainee, she developed the North West Severe Asthma Network and now acts as the regional strategic lead for specialised asthma services. She is also leading the development of integrated respiratory services across Central and South Manchester.

Julia Cream joined The King’s Fund as a Senior Associate in October 2014. She has worked on a number of projects and helped develop a toolkit to improve collaboration between finance and clinical teams.

Previously, Julia managed the communications and public affairs for a number of health charities and third sector organisations including Alzheimer’s Society, The Family and Childcare Trust, the Health Foundation and TimeBank. She has a particular interest in how personal experiences can be used to change and improve policy and practice. She has a PhD from the University of London.

field_job_title.value: GP and Chief Clinical Officer, NHS Bexley Clinical Commissioning Group

body.value:
Dr Nikita Kanani is a GP in south-east London and Chief Clinical Officer of NHS Bexley Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG). She has held a range of positions within the CCG to support the development of integrated care, primary care, clinical leadership and patient/public engagement and is passionate about improving service provision and population health.

Nikita has been honorary secretary of the National Association of Primary Care and national quality lead for the Faculty of Medical Leadership and Management, the CCG lead for community clinics and diabetes, medical adviser for NHS Direct, clinical lead for a large community provider trust, primary care trust lead for winter planning and screening assurance, and service modernisation lead for an acute trust. She is also a member of The King's Fund General Advisory Council.

Nikita is a Royal College of General Practitioners clinical commissioning champion. She holds an MSc in health care commissioning and has a postgraduate certificate in managing in health and social care.

field_job_title.value: Consultant Physician and Divisional Medical Director, Chelsea and Westminster Hospital

body.value:
Dilys Lai has been a consultant in respiratory and general medicine at Chelsea and Westminster Hospital since 2004. She became involved from an early stage in management projects having watched non-clinical managers struggle with processes which, with clinical input, were straightforward. She has held several management posts in the trust including Respiratory Service Lead, Divisional Research and Development Lead, Clinical Director for Medicine and Divisional Medical Director for Emergency and Integrated Care, taking up the latter post in 2015.

She undertook The King’s Fund Top Manager programme from May to November 2015.

Tessa Jelen is the chair of Breathe Easy Westminster, a community support group for people with respiratory conditions. After retiring from a charity that sent volunteers overseas and after a diagnosis of emphysema, community support for people with respiratory conditions became Tessa’s main priority. Breathe Easy Westminster supports more than 180 members and provides regular meetings and newsletters. Its Singing to Breathe group, encouraged by Christchurch's Sidney de Haan projects for arts and health, is going well.

Tessa also actively takes part in more than 14 patient involvement committees, including Healthwatch and the Central London Community Healthcare user panel, and is a member of CLAHRC and the NIHR Biomedical Research Centre patient and public panel, where she represents the need for respiratory support.

Susie is an Associate of The King’s Fund. She works with NHS trusts, consulting on the relationship between organisational culture and leadership capacity. Additionally, she was was executive director of organisational development and leadership development for Hamad Medical Corporation in Qatar.

As a result of her international experience in Europe, the Middle East and Asia, Susie has a particular interest in cross-cultural organisational and leadership issues alongside supporting alignment between organisational purpose, strategy and operational delivery.

She holds a first-class degree in education for health care professionals, an MSc in clinical research and a PhD in medical anthropology. She is also a qualified executive coach.

Catherine Beardshaw trained as a radiographer in Sheffield and worked as a clinician for 20 years across South Yorkshire and North Nottinghamshire.

She moved into general management in 1995 and obtained a Master of Business Administration [MBA] from Durham University. She worked at Leeds Infirmary and then Leeds Teaching Hospitals for 14 years, learning her trade as a general manager in most clinical specialties before becoming Director of Operations in 2002.

She became Chief Executive of Warrington and Halton Hospitals in 2006, taking it to foundation trust status in 2009. She then moved to Aintree University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust in Liverpool as Chief Executive Officer in 2011 before retiring in 2015 after 42 years in the NHS.

Patrick joined The King’s Fund in February 2016. He will be working closely with Nuffield Trust on the sustainability of social care services and the impact of spending reductions on older people and their carers.

Before joining the Fund, Patrick was Practice Development Manager (Policy) at the Social Care Institute for Excellence (SCIE), where he led on Care Act implementation and wrote SCIE’s guide to commissioning advocacy under the legislation. Most recently he led SCIE’s Policy Challenge Fund work in collaboration with the Health Foundation, the Institute for Government and PPL. Previously, Patrick worked as a health and social care commissioner in Newham.

Hong-Anh works in the Fund’s Library team. Alongside managing the day-to-day running of the library space and public enquiry service, she also leads on current awareness services and social media for the team. Her role includes cataloguing, training and providing research support to the Fund’s policy and leadership and organisational development staff.

Hong-Anh joined the Fund in 2010 with more than ten years' experience in different sectors, including higher education; services for children and young people; museums; and public libraries. She is a fully qualified librarian and graduated from the School of Information at the University of Sheffield in 2010 with a MA in librarianship.
body.summary: Biography of Hong-Anh Nguyen, Information Centre Manager.

body.value:
Alex joined The King’s Fund in March 2016, and is assistant director in the policy team, overseeing and leading policy projects on a range of health care, care quality and NHS system topics.

Before joining the Fund he worked at the Care Quality Commission (CQC), where he led development of the framework and approach for inspecting and rating hospitals, and at the Healthcare Commission, where he introduced risk-based regulation in the independent sector. Alex also led CQC’s work with the Department of Health on the policy and legal framework for quality regulation, and with the Department and other national bodies to agree roles and responsibilities for responding to serious concerns.

Before working in quality regulation, Alex worked in management in two NHS trusts. He has also worked at the Department of Health and at the World Health Organisation Regional Office for Europe, Copenhagen.
body.summary: Biography of Alex Baylis, Assistant Director of Policy.

body.value:
Laura Carter is PA to the Chief Executive and responsible for the day-to-day management of the chief executive’s office.

Before joining the Fund in 2007, Laura worked at BBC Worldwide as assistant to the company secretary. She has a background in administration within the health service, local government and the media, including the social work departments at both St Pancras Hospital and Great Ormond Street Hospital, Camden social services and the television production company Just Television, which investigated and publicised miscarriages of justice.

Caroline works in the events team, creating content for the annual programme of events and conferences. She currently leads on conferences and events relating to public health, digital health, patient experience, community services, older people and primary care.

Before joining the Fund in 2012, Caroline spent more than 10 years working on a wide range of events and conferences in the public and third sectors. As well as health, she has worked in local government and education and has experience working for and with public sector organisations to develop successful engagement events.

Claire works in the marketing team and is responsible for developing and implementing the marketing strategy for The King’s Fund’s conferences and online events. 

Before joining the Fund in 2014, Claire worked at the National Theatre for two years, where she was responsible for marketing West End shows including: War horse, The curious incident of the dog in the night-time and One man, two guvnors. Claire graduated from Exeter University in 2012 with a degree in English.

Hinal has more than nine years' experience organising a wide range of events including major industry conferences, dinners, receptions, exhibitions and social events. As part of the events team at The King’s Fund, her focus is on the logistical operations for these events, working collaboratively with internal and external stakeholders to ensure successful experiences.

field_job_title.value: Deputy Head of Events and Partnerships

body.value:
Kieran leads the Fund’s partnership work with external organisations through the Corporate partnerships membership programmes, with event sponsors and partners. He also works with organisations looking to commission other work from the Fund. His role focuses on developing mutually beneficial relationships with existing and new partner organisations.

Before joining the Fund in 2016, Kieran spent four years working at the Cystic Fibrosis Trust and Shelter. He developed and managed six and seven-figure partnerships with a range of companies across the health care, financial, advertising and fast-moving consumer goods sectors. His areas of interest include reducing health inequalities; the role digital technologies play in giving people greater control over their health and wellbeing; and supporting health and care organisations to work in partnership with each other and with other sectors to improve the health and wellbeing of all.

Working in the communications team, Beth co-ordinates the delivery of content and communications across The King’s Fund website and social media channels. She is primarily responsible for managing the editorial process for blogs, along with digital content for a range of publications and projects. She oversees and manages the corporate Twitter account on a day-to-day basis.

Before joining The King’s Fund in January 2016, Beth worked for several years in project management for a digital contract publishing agency before moving into website management in the third sector, working for Alzheimer’s Society and the Children’s Commissioner for England.

Emmet works in the communications team and is responsible for managing the marketing of The King’s Fund’s leadership and organisational development services. He also leads on a number of ad hoc communications projects.

Before he joined the Fund in 2011, Emmet worked across a number of communications roles in the public and not-for-profit sectors at national, regional and local level. Emmet has a CAM diploma in marketing communications from the Chartered Institute of Marketing, as well as an MSc in development studies and an MA in diplomatic studies.

James works in the communications team and overseas all email marketing activity for the Fund. He joined the Fund in March 2016 just as the marketing team finalised its new email marketing strategy, so most of his time will be spent driving the strategy forward.

James previously worked as digital marketing officer at Age UK, where he designed, created, deployed and analysed all email marketing communications. He has more than five years of digital marketing experience, with advanced knowledge in email marketing.

Lisa works in the communications team and leads The King’s Fund’s programme of written outputs, overseeing planning, co-ordination and scheduling. She has a lead role in developing the Fund’s approach to communicating insights and learning from its work.

Before joining the Fund in 2011, Lisa spent eight years as a freelance editor and writer. She has a background in scientific publishing, working on a range of journals and magazines for member and third sector organisations, including the Chartered Society of Physiotherapy, the Royal Society of Chemistry, and Healthlink Worldwide. Lisa also spent 10 years working in antenatal education for both the NHS and the National Childbirth Trust. She has a Masters in global health from Brighton and Sussex Medical School.

Lynsey Hawker works in the Fund’s Library team. As an information specialist she fields incoming queries to the enquiry desk, undertakes literature searches for both internal and external clients and contributes to the regular current awareness bulletins produced by the team.

Before joining the Fund in 2016, Lynsey was librarian at Barnet Enfield and Haringey Mental Health NHS Trust where she was responsible for providing library and information services to staff. Previously, Lynsey spent eight years working as an information professional at St George’s University of London Library in Tooting.

Nikki works in the Fund’s Library team as an information specialist. As part of her role Nikki creates the twice-weekly health management and policy alert . In addition to this, she works in the enquiry service and contributes to the cataloguing of resources for the library database.

Nikki had more than 20 years’ experience of library work, including roles in the construction and commercial property sectors, before joining the Fund in 2008. She has a BSc in information and computing from Loughborough University.

Gemma works in the finance team and is responsible for the Fund's management accounts and forecasts. Her role includes providing a dedicated and professional management accounting service to all departments in the Fund, delivering accurate and highly analytical management accounting information to key decision-makers in the Fund. Gemma completed her ACCA qualification in 2015.

Gemma joined the Fund in 2016. She previously worked at the British Heart Foundation, where she provided financial advice and support to all charitable expenditure divisions. Gemma has almost 10 years’ experience in finance, including in the publishing and manufacturing sectors.

Lucy left The Fund in March 2023.

Lucy works in the operations team and manages governance arrangements for the board of trustees and its sub-committees and for the Fund’s trading company, KEHF. Lucy also contributes to the internal control of the organisation by co-ordinating the work of the internal auditors and the risk management process.

Before joining the Fund in 2004, Lucy worked for the British Association for the Advancement of Science in a similar role.
body.summary: Biography of Lucy Johnson-Brown, Governance Support Manager.

body.value:
Moi works in the operations team. She works with and across teams to understand needs, and identify, deliver and evaluate improvement across our systems, processes and culture. She brings inclusion and meaningful engagement to the Fund’s improvement method, having co-led a five-year business change programme and, more recently, having led the internal engagement process for developing the Fund’s strategy for 2020–24.

Moi joined the Fund in 2012 in the leadership and organisational development team. Her background is in developing business systems that are led by people and focus on impact. Before joining the Fund, she spent eight years working in a consultancy for the not-for-profit sector where she managed the business, marketing, events and communications.

Clare works in the Policy team, managing and delivering large policy and cross-organisational projects. During her time at The King’s Fund she has worked on a broad range of projects, including grants programmes, the GSK Awards, the Wanless Review, medical professionalism, the Barker Commission on the future of health and social care and integrated care programmes.

Before joining the Fund in 2003, she gained first-hand experience of the NHS as an occupational therapy technician at the Whittington Hospital, London, enabling patients to be safely discharged from hospital to home. She has previously worked for a number of corporate organisations in business management roles.

She promotes healthy living as a volunteer event director for parkrun in south-east London.

Mel heads up a team that works to continuously improve internal ways of working and business processes at the Fund. Mel’s role includes oversight of strategic and operational planning and risk management. 

Mel has more than 15 years’ experience in business development, operational management, relationship and projects/programmes management working in commercial, public and non-governmental organisations spanning the health, education, training and research sectors.
body.summary: Biography of Melanie Chandler, Head of Operations.

body.value:
Rachele’s programme portfolio in the leadership and organisational development team includes programmes such as Senior Clinical Leaders, Emerging Clinical Leaders and The King’s Fund study tours. Rachele also co-ordinates and supports the Fund’s clinical leadership workstream and the leadership associates register. She is passionate about working for the health and social care sector and enjoys her role in ensuring the Fund’s programmes run well so that participants gain the most from their experience.

Before joining The King’s Fund in September 2009, Rachele worked in the training and development sector for CSE-Demos and Hemsley Fraser in London and for the corporate events sector in Italy.

Rachele is originally from Italy and came to the United Kingdom in 1997 to study international management and French at Bradford University. Rachele can fluently speak Italian, English and French and very basic Russian.

Chris works within the Fund’s corporate partnership team, managing relationships with our partner businesses, while protecting the Fund’s reputation for independence and quality in line with our ethical partnerships policy.

His role includes building relationships with potential new corporate partners and supporters, the planning and management of individual partnerships, and the development and delivery of partner events, including seminars, dinners and briefings.

Jessica left The Fund in March 2023

Jessica works in the finance team, overseeing the Fund's income, expenditure and cash with the support of others in the finance team, budget holders and staff at the Fund.

Jessica joined the Fund in 2016 from the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations, where she was director of finance for three years. Jessica has experience in a number of other sectors, including working at J Sainsbury plc, Pentland Brands and Hackney Community College, starting as a trainee at Deloitte. She is a chartered accountant and completed her Masters in voluntary sector management at Cass Business School in 2015 having originally studied politics, philosophy and economics at Worcester College, Oxford.

Tracy Nottage joined The King’s Fund in 2004. She is a senior programme coordinator in Leadership and Organisational Development, working across a variety of open programmes, commissioned pieces of work and other projects.

Before joining the Fund, Tracy worked as an events coordinator and office manager within the financial securities industry. She set up her own events partnership in 2002, catering for the same market. Prior to this Tracy worked at Ernst & Young, initially in the audit department, then corporate finance.

Chris works in the leadership and organisational development team and is responsible for the team’s finances, business processes and contracts. Chris also assists colleagues with business development proposals. Before becoming finance and contract manager, Chris was a programme co-ordinator, working on open and commissioned programmes, then acting business manager.

Before joining the Fund in 2011, Chris was project manager and then development adviser for the Learning and Skills Network, supporting the delivery of consultancy, resources and training events to schools and colleges. Chris has also worked as an executive officer in several government departments, including the Home Office, Cabinet Office and UK Trade and Investment.

Chris studied history and philosophy at the universities of Wolverhampton and Birmingham.

field_job_title.value: Director of Patient Safety, National Patient Safety Agency; National Campaign Director for Sign up to Safety, NHS England

body.value:
Suzette Woodward has spent her life working in the NHS; first as a paediatric intensive care nurse and then for the last two decades as a patient safety specialist.

A former executive board director at the National Patient Safety Agency and the NHS Litigation Authority, she is currently leading the Sign up to Safety campaign for the NHS in England.

Suzette has an MSc in clinical risk and a doctorate in patient safety implementation.

Sally specialises in organisational change and leadership development and has 20 years’ experience in leadership roles. Before joining the Fund, Sally worked at Ashridge Business School. She has worked with a range of international and UK clients including: the International Red Cross, WHO, Unilever, Credit Suisse, British Airways, and Pfizer and with universities, local government organisations and NHS trusts.

Sally previously held the role of Director of Change, Civil Service, where she created an internal consultancy for government departments specialising in culture change; she has also worked at KPMG and the BBC.

Sally holds Masters degrees in organisational psychology and organisational consulting. She is an accredited coach and co-authored Organisational change: perspectives on theory and practice.

Rebecca is a part-time nurse in the community in north London and also works as an executive coach and organisational development consultant. She is a qualified coach has an MSc in organisational change.

After joining the NHS as a nurse, Rebecca graduated from the Management Training Scheme and then spent 20 years working in management, holding several director positions. The focus of her work has always been connecting and improving the 'system' of care.

Matthew joined The King's Fund as a part-time Visiting Fellow in August 2016. He was a consultant in general medicine and gastroenterology at Sandwell and West Birmingham Hospitals from 2002 to 2018, where he also worked as Group Director for Medicine and Emergency Care. 

Matthew carried out his clinical training in Manchester and north-west England. He has a Masters in medical leadership from Warwick University, which has given him an insight into the opportunities afforded by understanding different approaches to health care across the United Kingdom and overseas.

In 2018 he took up the post of Executive Medical Director at Walsall Healthcare NHS Trust, where he continues to work as gastroenterologist in the out-patient and endoscopy departments.

Tom joined the policy team at The King’s Fund in September 2016 for a two-month placement as part of the NHS Graduate Management Training Scheme. While in the policy team, Tom co-authored a report on the progress of policy changes required to implement the NHS five year forward view.

Before joining the Fund, Tom worked for the informatics team at Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust. He has also worked for NHS England handling complaints and enquiries. He began his NHS career in 2009 at Leeds Primary Care Trust.

Tom is currently studying for a postgraduate diploma in health informatics at University College London and a postgraduate certificate in health care leadership with the University of Birmingham. He has a BSc in geography from the University of Sheffield.

Before becoming unwell, Jane was an account director at a leading public relations company and a lecturer in contemporary communications at University of The Arts London. As a result of her experience she is now active in campaigning for improvement in mental health services. She has worked closely with West London Mental Health Trust as a service-user consultant since 2008, developing innovative co-production projects that put experts by experience in equal partnership with professionals. In 2015 she became chief executive of West London Collaborative, a community interest company that delivers authentic partnerships to help NHS organisations and commissioners solve complex problems using co-production and other innovative tools.

Emily is a GP trainee who joined the King’s Fund as part of an innovative training post at Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust. She is interested in child and adolescent health, diabetes and patient education.

Emily spent several years training as a paediatric doctor, and completed her paediatric exams before moving to train in general practice. She undertook her medical training at the University of Manchester.

Harry is a researcher in the policy team. Before joining the Fund in 2016, Harry worked for three years at Ipsos MORI’s Social Research Institute, focusing on health research, working with a range of health sector organisations, including NHS England and the Department of Health. At Ipsos MORI, Harry worked on the GP Patient Survey, and also had a special interest in speaking to the public about their health data and in emerging health technologies.

He holds a Masters in European language, culture and history from UCL.

Vicki has worked as both an internal and external consultant in the areas of organisational, team and personal development for over 20 years.

In her early consulting years she focused on team facilitation and effective team working in the NHS and the establishment of primary care groups. She then moved into an internal consulting role for Pfizer, working on leadership coaching and development and went on to be a partner and business director in an international organisation development consultancy. She came back into the health care sector in 2012 as Head of Leadership and Organisational Development for Nuffield Health, where she began piloting the integration of mindfulness into leadership development interventions.

With a Masters degree in organisation consulting and a postgraduate certificate in business and executive coaching, Vicki now works independently with many different organisations, sectors and industries predominantly in the areas of leadership, team development and executive coaching.

Rt Hon Jacqui Smith is currently Chair in Common of Barts Health and Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Trust having previously chaired University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust for eight years. She is the Chair of Sandwell Children's Trust. She is also Chair of the Jo Cox Foundation and the Precious Trust – a Birmingham-based charity formed with Marcia Shakespeare to support girls at risk of gang violence. She works in the Middle East and Africa on political development projects.

Jacqui was MP for Redditch between 1997 and 2010 and served as a government minister for 10 years from 1999 to 2009, during which time she was a health minister and the UK’s first female Home Secretary.

She has a weekly podcast called 'For the Many' and is a weekly contributor to Good Morning Britain and frequent political commentator.

Paul has been Director of the Institute for Fiscal Studies since January 2011. He is a visiting professor at University College London.

Paul has published and broadcast extensively on the economics of public policy including tax, welfare, inequality and poverty, pensions, education, climate change, and public finances. He has written books on pensions, tax and inequality and is one of the authors of The Mirrlees Review of tax system design.

Paul has previously worked at the Financial Services Authority and was Chief Economist at the Department for Education and Director of Public Spending in HM Treasury, as well as Deputy Head of the UK Government Economic Service.

Paul is currently a member of the Council and Executive Committee of the Royal Economic Society, and is also a member of the Climate Change Committee and of the Banking Standards Board. He is also on the board of the Office of Tax Simplification. He has previously served on the Economic and Social Research Council and was a founder council member of the Pensions Policy Institute. He has led reviews of the policy of auto-enrolment into pensions for the Department for Work and Pensions and of price statistics for the UK Statistics Authority.

Dr Jane Collins qualified in medicine at Birmingham University. In 2019 Jane became a non-executive director at University College Hospital London. She is also a non-executive director and Vice-Chair on the Board of The Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital.

Previously, Jane was Chief Executive of Marie Curie from 2012 to 2019. While at Marie Curie she held a number of external roles, including co-chair of the Ambitions in End of Life Care Group; and member of the Cicely Saunders Institute Advisory Council, the Palliative Care Leadership Network and the HELIX Centre of End of Life Care Steering Committee. Jane was also Chair of the London Clinical Senate until January 2018.

Jane joined Great Ormond Street Hospital, London, in 1994 and became Chief Executive of Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children and Chief Executive of GOSH Children's Charity in 2001. Before that Jane was a consultant paediatric neurologist at Guy's Hospital, London.

She is an honorary fellow of UCL and of the Institute of Child Health, UCL.

Dominic Dodd is chair of UCLPartners the health innovation partnership, and of UCL Health Alliance, the healthcare collaborative based in north central London. He also chairs Skin Analytics, a health tech company.

He is a trustee of UK Biobank, the biomedical research resource.

Previously he chaired two NHS trusts: from 2010–2021 he was chair of The Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust, one of the UK’s largest acute trusts; and from 2019-2023 he was chair of The Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital NHS Trust which specialises in tertiary neuro-muscular-skeletal services, education and research. 

Before his time in health care, Dominic was a managing partner of Marakon Associates, a strategy consulting firm.

Simon is the founding Chairman of the Investor Forum CIC, which provides a platform for institutional investors to collectively engage with UK-listed companies on long-term strategic issues. He is also Chairman of McInroy and Wood and TS Lombard as well as a Non-Executive Director of Fidelity Funds SICAV.

Previously, Simon Fraser spent 28 years at Fidelity International after graduating from St Andrews University. During his time at Fidelity he worked in the United States, Europe and Asia and helped to build the company’s network of international investment professionals ultimately becoming Chief Investment Officer. Since leaving Fidelity in 2009 he has served on a number of boards including Barclays plc and Ashmore plc. He also served as Chairman of F&C Investment Trust and Merchants Trust.

Kathy works in the Fund’s Library team as an information specialist. Her role includes handling enquiries, identifying resources to include on the library database, creating topical reading lists and undertaking literature searches for staff and external clients.

Kathy joined the Fund in 1992. She has a MA in librarianship from Sheffield University.

Siva is chief analyst in the policy team, leading on projects covering NHS funding, finances, productivity and performance.

Before joining the Fund in 2017, Siva was head of analysis at NHS Providers – the membership body for NHS trusts and foundation trusts – where he led a team focused on NHS finances, workforce and informatics. Previously, he was an analyst in the Department of Health working on medicines policy and urgent and emergency care. 

Siva is a member of the Office of Health Economics policy committee and chairs the National Payment Strategy Advisory Group for NHS England and NHS Improvement.

field_job_title.value: Senior Press and Public Affairs Manager

body.value:
Gemma works in the communications team where she is responsible for overseeing the Fund’s relationships with key stakeholders and parliamentary audiences and for securing media coverage for the Fund’s work. She also manages stakeholder breakfast events and monitors developments in the external environment.

Before joining the Fund in 2013, Gemma worked in the communications team of ukactive, the not-for-profit body for the physical activity sector. She also spent a number of years working for a Member of Parliament and as a freelance production journalist.
body.summary: Biography of Gemma Umali, Senior Press and Public Affairs Manager.

body.value:
Deborah is part of the leadership and organisational development team and has more than 20 years’ experience in the health care sector. For the past 10 years, she has worked as a consultant and strategic adviser to NHS organisations and boards, most recently as a partner in an international consulting practice. She began her career as an NHS management trainee and has held director posts in acute, commissioning and mental health organisations.

Deborah is passionate about supporting organisations to develop compassionate cultures that deliver high-quality care. Her interests include using occupational psychology and evidence-based approaches to develop leadership, OD strategy and OD interventions that make a demonstrable difference for staff and patients. She is experienced in team development and facilitation, and leadership and organisational development working with groups ranging in size from small teams to whole organisations.
body.summary: Biography of Deborah Homa, Senior Consultant, Leadership and Organisational Development.

body.value:
Leo left the Fund in January 2022.

Leo was a researcher in the policy team. Before joining the Fund, he worked at Demos, the cross-party think-tank. He has also worked in the policy development team at Cancer Research UK. He first worked on health care policy while at Reform, a think-tank focused on public services. He began his career at the Economic and Social Research Council.
body.summary: Biography of Leo Ewbank, Researcher, Policy.

body.value:
Nishma Manek is a GP trainee in London. She has taken a year out of her GP training to be a Clinical Fellow to the National Medical Director, Sir Bruce Keogh. This year, she has been working for the Director of Primary Care at NHS England on the GP Forward View. She has also established an innovative leadership development programme for GP trainees and newly qualified GPs.

As part of her medical degree, she completed an intercalated BSc in Healthcare Management at Imperial College, which sparked an interest in NHS leadership and service reform. She then completed an Academic Foundation Programme in Public Health, during which she was selected to attend Michael Porter’s course in Value-based Healthcare at Harvard Business School.

She currently sits on the NW London Faculty board for the Royal College of GPs, and blogs about her experiences as a trainee for The Guardian and Pulse magazine.
body.summary: Biography of Nish Manek, GP Trainee.

body.value:
Dr Tom Nutt is CEO of Meningitis Now. Previously, he was Chief Executive of Healthwatch Essex until June 2017.

Prior to this, Tom worked in a variety of policy-related roles at Essex County Council, having originally been an academic historian based at Magdalene College, Cambridge, where he lectured and published on aspects of British socio-economic and demographic history, including the history of the family and the history of social welfare.
body.summary: Biography of Dr Tom Nutt, Chief Executive of Healthwatch Essex.

body.value:
Jane Anderson is a visiting fellow at The King’s Fund and a consultant physician in HIV medicine at Homerton University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust. She also works as a clinician and researcher in HIV medicine in East London. Her work focuses on the needs of ethnic minority and migrant populations in relation to HIV in the UK, with a particular interest in HIV care for women and families.

From 2013–16 she was seconded part-time to Public Health England and currently chairs its External Advisory Group for HIV and Sexual/Reproductive Health and the tripartite partnership board for Sexual Assault Referral Centres. She represents London clinicians on the NHS England Clinical Reference Group for HIV. Jane is Chair of the National AIDS Trust and a past Chair of the British HIV Association. She was appointed CBE in 2015.
body.summary: Biography of Jane Anderson, Visiting Fellow.

field_job_title.value: Respiratory and General Physician, Royal Shrewsbury Hospital

body.value: Elin Roddy is a respiratory and general physician at Royal Shrewsbury Hospital and is lead clinician for smoking cessation, lung cancer and end-of-life care at the Shrewsbury and Telford Hospitals NHS Trust. She also sits on the Mortality and Morbidity Group and on the Local Negotiating Committee at the trust.
body.summary: Biography of Elin Roddy.

body.value: Jane Shepherd is a graphic designer working in the HIV and sexual and reproductive health and rights sector. She was diagnosed with HIV in 1990. She currently sits on the Steering Group of UK-CAB, a network of HIV advocates, and is a community representative on the UCL PRIME Study and The King's Fund’s research into the future of HIV services in England.
body.summary: Biography of Jane Shepherd.

body.value:
After 6 years, Durka has decided to leave to pursue her career outside of The King’s Fund. During her time with us, Durka has spearheaded work on population health and reducing inequalities and brought both into the very centre of our work. We wish her well in the next phase of her career.

Durka was a senior consultant and programme director in the leadership and organisational development team at The King’s Fund, and a medical consultant in public health medicine. Durka leads many population health, systems transformation and clinical leadership initiatives across the UK.
body.summary: Biography of Durka Dougall, Senior Consultant in Leadership and Organisational Development.

body.value:
Dan works in the policy team at the Fund, where his particular areas of interest include patient and staff experience and public perceptions of the NHS and social care system.

Before joining The King’s Fund in April 2017, Dan was Head of Insight and Feedback at NHS England. The Insight and Feedback team is responsible for the commissioning and running of a number of national surveys including the GP Patient Survey, the Cancer Patient Experience Survey and the Staff Survey. In addition, the team oversees the patient-reported outcomes measures (PROMs) programme as well as the implementation and development of the friends and family test.

Dan has also worked as Research Director at Ipsos MORI, specialising in public attitudes to the NHS and social care. He has a Masters in public health from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine.
body.summary: Biography of Dan Wellings, Senior Fellow, Policy.

body.value:
Maria is an independent health care consultant working with organisations across the NHS and Independent sector supporting leadership development and health care governance. Previously, Maria worked for Nuffield Health, first in its Hospitals Division, focusing on quality and patient safety in senior management roles, and later joining the learning and development team contributing to the organisation’s OD agenda.

Before joining Nuffield Health, Maria was part of the clinical leadership team at the Royal College of Nursing, where she focused on team effectiveness and leadership development. Maria is a registered nurse, who has held clinical and managerial roles in both primary and secondary care organisations in the NHS. She has also worked in the higher education sector.

She has a degree in managing health care delivery and has undertaken postgraduate studies in leadership in health and social care. She is an accredited Myers Briggs practitioner and an ILM executive coach and mentor.
body.summary: Biography of Maria Robinson.

body.value:
Dharini supports the corporate partnerships team in its work to drive income growth across three membership programmes. She assists with the Fund’s corporate partner and supporter events by ensuring logistics run smoothly, as well as marketing events to relevant audiences.

Before joining the Fund, Dharini spent two years working in the fundraising team at the Lymphoma Association working on national community-fundraising events and charity-of-the-year partnerships. She has also spent time as a volunteer undertaking research and delivering awareness events for a human rights organisation.
body.summary: Biography of Dharini Roula, Partnerships Account Executive.

body.value:
Ian manages the Fund's day-to-day online presence and finds different ways to share messages with new and existing audiences.  He creates, commissions and edits digital content, oversees The King's Fund podcast and is involved in broader audio-video work too.

Ian joined the Fund in 2016. Previously he led the communications work at the International Alliance of Patients’ Organizations. He has worked in communications roles across the third sector.
body.summary: Biography of Ian Ford, Digital Manager.

field_job_title.value: Speech and Language Therapist, Clinical Director Allied Health Professions, NHS Improvement and Deputy Chief AHP Officer

body.value:
Dr Joanne Fillingham is a speech and language therapist who qualified in 1998 and completed a PhD in 2005. Since then she has worked in clinical and leadership roles across primary, community and secondary care settings at a local, regional and national level. She was the first to be appointed to the role of Clinical Fellow to the Chief Allied Health Professions Officer in NHS England and led the delivery of Allied health professions into action. She joined NHS Improvement in December 2016 as the first Clinical Director for Allied Health Professions were she provides expertise on how NHS Improvement can work to support trusts in service improvement and the professional development of AHPs.

Joanne is also passionate about harnessing the use of social media to transform care and co-founded @WeAHPs with @NaomiMcVey, @HelenOwen3 and the support of #WeCommunities.
body.summary: Biography of Dr Joanne Fillingham.

body.value:
Nicholas works in the Information and Knowledge Services team, contributing to the cataloguing of resources for the library database. In addition he is part of the enquiry team, and produces a fortnightly internal press bulletin.

Before joining the Fund Nick worked in various library and archive roles, including at the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority, and a number of council run libraries in Leeds.
body.summary: Biography of Nicholas Willsher, Information Assistant.

field_job_title.value: Clinical Artificial Intelligence and Predictive Analytics Researcher, King’s College London

body.value: Hugh Harvey is a radiologist with a research MD from Europe’s leading cancer research institute, the ICR, where he was twice awarded Science Writer of the Year. He spent a year at Babylon Health, a digital health and artificial intelligence start-up, working in clinical artificial intelligence (AI) and predictive analytics, before becoming a consultant in academic radiology with research interests in AI as applied to medical imaging at King’s College London. He also sits on the Radiology Informatics Committee at the Royal College of Radiologists.
body.summary: Biography of Hugh Harvey.

body.value:
Before joining The King’s Fund in September 2017, Simon spent almost 10 years as Director of Policy at the older people’s charity Independent Age, researching and campaigning on issues including care home quality, unmet needs for care, social care funding and the social care workforce. He was vice-chair of the Care and Support Alliance in 2017.

Simon has wide experience in policy, communications and journalism, including as Director of Communications at Citizens Advice. He has also worked for ActionAid, in the commercial sector for Guinness and in BBC local radio.
body.summary: Biography of Simon Bottery, Senior Fellow, Social Care.

field_job_title.value: Head of Systems Partnerships, Moorfields Eye Hospital

body.value:
Mark Redhead is Head of Systems Partnerships, Moorfields Eye Hospital. Prior to this, he was Head of Strategy and Planning at the Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust.

Mark has worked in health for 20 years. In the first ten years, he was representing academic medicine at the BMA; promoting teaching and research remains very important to him. He went on to be head of policy at what is now NHS Providers, representing trusts in the 2013 health reforms and working on development programmes for boards and foundation trust governors. This development focus continued at Monitor, where he led work on clinical engagement, service line management and system resilience. In his current role, he is particularly keen to advance the population health agenda. His career is characterised by sense-making and giving people the tools to do the job, which provoked his recent interest in coaching for individuals and teams.

Dr Stephen Dunn is Chief Executive of West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust. 

Dr Dunn worked for a number of years in the Department of Health, where he played a key part in the Wanless Review, the establishment of foundation trusts, and the White Paper Our health, our care, our say. He was also the architect of the innovative Hinchingbrooke franchise and introduced the Friends and Family test into the NHS, which was endorsed by the Prime Minister for wider roll-out.

Prior to joining West Suffolk, Dr Dunn was a national director at the Trust Development Authority, overseeing 24 NHS trusts and £8 billion of health care spend in the south region.

In 2011, Dr Dunn received the ‘Outstanding Contribution by an Individual’ award from Health Investor. He is also an international authority on the economics of John Kenneth Galbraith, having published The economics of John Kenneth Galbraith with Cambridge University Press and the four-volume reference collection, John Kenneth Galbraith: the economic legacy with Routledge.

In 2000, Dr Dunn received the prestigious K William Kapp prize from one of Europe’s largest economics associations. He is a visiting professor at the London School of Economics and the University of the West of England.

Aneira Thomas was born at one minute past midnight on 5 July 1948, making her first baby in Great Britain to be born into the NHS. She was named after Aneurin Bevan, the minister for health at the time who led on the plan for the NHS. Aneira spent her career working in the NHS as a mental health nurse (her four sisters were also nurses, and her daughter is now a paramedic), and continues to be an active supporter of the NHS, speaking out on a range of issues in the media and at public rallies.

field_job_title.value: Director of the Centre for the History of Medicine, University of Warwick

body.value:
Professor Mathew Thomson is Director of the Centre for the History of Medicine and Professor for the Department of History at the University of Warwick.

His research on the cultural history of the NHS is supported by a Wellcome Trust Investigator Award and involves collaboration with co-investigator Professor Roberta Bivins and a team of researchers. One of the aims of the project has been to investigate the history of a relationship between the NHS and the public. Findings from this research as well as opportunities for the public to contribute can be found on the People's history of the NHS website.

Tricia left the Fund in June 2021.

Tricia is an experienced consultant and coach. She has 20 years’ experience of external consultancy work in government departments, local authorities, voluntary and private sector organisations and 10 years’ experience leading an internal consultancy team of organisational development specialists in a Scottish health board.

She has worked extensively at board and senior management levels and with teams in difficulty, start-ups, restructures and mergers.

Among her consulting skills she has specialist skills in the design and facilitation of dialogue processes for resolving organisational issues and helping groups find ways to develop collaborative styles of leadership. These skills are best employed where there is a need for open conversation about complex issues, usually helping stakeholders to find a collective way through the issues. Collaborative leadership is a particular area of interest and current research. 

Tricia’s work at The King’s Fund included directing the Leadership for Consultants programme and the Care homes, housing, health and social care learning network as well as the Leading Breakthrough Conversations programme. She also consulted with and coached teams and individuals attempting service and practice transformations across Health and Social Care.

Matthew was a Visiting Senior Fellow at the Fund.

In October 2018 he started as Interim Chief Executive of Croydon Health Services – a combined acute and community trust. In addition to leading the Trust, he is working on how they integrate more closely with clinical commissioning groups and other partners in Croydon.

Matthew has more than 25 years’ experience in the NHS, having been Chief Executive of East Kent Hospitals University Foundation Trust before joining The King's Fund, and Chief Executive of Brighton and Sussex University Hospitals NHS Trust for three years before this. 

He has led the Kent Cancer Alliance, chaired the Kent Surrey and Sussex Clinical Research Network, and has been a member of the Health Education England Kent Surrey and Sussex governing body. He has also worked with the Care Quality Commission.

Matthew’s early career was in Berkshire, Surrey and Sussex in operational and director roles, including as Chief Operating Officer at East Kent Hospitals and subsequently Chief Executive of Salisbury NHS Foundation Trust. He has also held a number of national roles for the Department of Health including developing the delivery plan for the 18-week referral-to-treatment target and being the first trust special administrator.
body.summary: Biography of Matthew Kershaw, Visiting Senior Fellow.

body.value:
Kane joined the policy team at The King’s Fund in September 2017 for a two-month placement as part of the NHS Graduate Management Training Scheme. While at the Fund, Kane has co-authored a briefing on the rising pharmaceuticals expenditure and written an accompanying blog. 

For his first graduate scheme placement, Kane worked as a project manager at Somerset Clinical Commissioning Group. He will be working in the surgical division at University Hospitals Bristol NHS Foundation Trust for his final placement. 

Kane is currently studying for a postgraduate diploma in health care leadership with the University of Birmingham. He has a BSc in biomedical sciences from the University of Southampton.

field_job_title.value: Medical Director for Acute Care, NHS England

body.value:
Professor Keith Willett is the Medical Director for Acute Care and Emergency Preparedness to NHS England and is the Professor of Orthopaedic Trauma Surgery at the University of Oxford.

An NHS consultant surgeon for 24 years he has extensive experience of trauma care, driving service transformation and healthcare management. He has taught surgery and leadership extensively across the NHS and internationally.

In his current role, he has the national medical oversight of acute NHS services ranging from pre-hospital and ambulance services, emergency departments, urgent surgery, acute medicine, children’s and national major incidents. He leads the transformation of the urgent and emergency care services across the NHS in England.

field_job_title.value: Director of Communications, Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust

body.value: Michelle Dixon has been Director of Communications at Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust since 2014. She also leads on the organisation’s patient and public involvement strategy. She was previously Director of Communications at the British Medical Association and, before that, Interim Director of Communications at the Cabinet Office and Director of Communications at The King’s Fund.
Bilal is on the Imperial College GP training scheme. Between August 2017 and February 2018 he completed a six-month placement in The King’s Fund’s policy team.

field_job_title.value: Managing Director, Ipsos MORI Social Research Institute

body.value: Bobby Duffy is Managing Director of Public Affairs in the UK and Global Director of the Ipsos Social Research Institute. He leads a team of around 220 researchers in London, Manchester, Edinburgh and Brussels. He has worked across most public policy areas in his career, and has been seconded to the Prime Minister’s Strategy Unit and the Centre for Analysis of Social Exclusion (CASE) at the London School of Economics. Bobby is a Visiting Senior Research Fellow at the Policy Institute, King’s College London, and sits on several boards for think tanks and universities, as well as the Campaign for Social Science.

Deborah left the Fund in January 2022.

Deborah was a senior analyst in the policy team with a particular interest in how to communicate data effectively. Before joining the Fund in 2018, Deborah was the analysis and research manager at NHS Providers, leading their member survey programme and analysis of NHS performance data. Previously, Deborah worked for GovernWell, the national training programme for NHS foundation trust governors. Deborah has an MSc in forensic and biological anthropology from Bournemouth University.

Laura Fulcher is the founder of Mission Remission, a non-profit organisation dedicated to empowering cancer survivors to move forward after treatment. She has been a clinical commissioning group lay member championing patient involvement and has written for national newspapers and magazines on health and education. She is a qualified secondary school English teacher, has founded projects to develop the literacy of disadvantaged children and has trained teachers in Africa.

field_job_title.value: Director of Partnerships and Evaluation at Shine Cancer Support

body.value: Ceinwen Giles is Director of Partnerships and Evaluation at Shine Cancer Support and has extensive experience in the charity sector both in the UK and internationally. Before joining Shine, she worked in the field of international development where her clients included large non-governmental organisations, the United Nations and the Department for International Development. Ceinwen was diagnosed with stage IV non-Hodgkin lymphoma six weeks after her daughter was born prematurely. It was this experience that developed her interest in patient involvement in the UK's health care system. In addition to her work with Shine, Ceinwen is a trustee for the Point of Care Foundation and is a member of the General Advisory Council of The King's Fund.

Paul leads the finance, IT, business operations and commercial teams within the finance and operations directorate. Paul’s responsibilities include managing the Fund's finances and investments; providing effective business systems and processes; and generating income from commercial events and facilities.

Paul has worked for 20 years in senior finance and broader leadership roles in the charity sector based in the UK, Malawi, Namibia and the Netherlands. Paul is a trained executive coach and has an active interest in leadership and organisational development

Richard is responsible for the information technology strategy at The King’s Fund and for making sure that the IT team delivers the technology and associated services that the Fund’s staff and visitors need, while keeping its data and systems secure.

Before joining the Fund in September 2017, Richard has spent 20 years in senior IT roles across a wide range of sectors including financial services, outsourcing, software and social housing. He joined the Fund from the Royal College of Surgeons.

Deborah works in the policy team. She has a particular interest in health inequalities: her recent research topics at The King’s Fund include support for unpaid carers, disabled people’s involvement in health and care design, and the NHS’s role in tackling poverty.

She is currently the learning lead for Healthy Communities Together, a four-year collaboration with The National Lottery Community Fund to support local partnership working.

Before joining the Fund in 2018, Deborah worked for two years as a senior analyst at the Care Quality Commission. Deborah holds a PhD in sociology and social policy from the University of Leeds, which explored inequalities in disabled people’s access to sustainable lifestyles.

Sarah supports digital communications activity across The King’s Fund website and social media channels, and is responsible for creating, editing and publishing a range of digital content. In her role she oversees and manages the corporate Twitter account on a day-to-day basis, as well as working to develop the Fund's social media strategy. She is a scriptwriter, producer and editor for The King's Fund podcast.  

Before joining The King’s Fund in June 2018, Sarah worked as a marketing executive in the higher education sector before moving into digital communications and content production in the third sector. She has experience in digital storytelling, marketing and online communications.

Jake left the Fund in October 2021.

Jake was a researcher in the policy team, supporting the Fund with its responsive and monitoring work. He helped ensure the Fund had a good overview of key developments in health and social care, including scoping new and emerging issues.

Before joining The King’s Fund, Jake worked at Age UK in their national policy and research team supporting their quantitative analysis of health and social care data and their influencing work for the improvement of later life in England.

He has a BA in natural sciences and an MSci in systems biology from the University of Cambridge.

Danielle works within the events and partnerships team managing relationships with the Fund’s partner companies.

Her role focuses on developing relationships with both existing and potential partners and supporters including the planning and delivery of dinners, roundtables and seminars.

Before joining the Fund, Danielle was part of the management team at Wallacespace, an offsite meetings and events company.

Danielle has a sociology and politics degree and a Masters in international studies from the University of Exeter.

field_job_title.value: Director of Leadership and Organisational Development

body.value:
Suzie leads the leadership and organisational development team at The King’s Fund.

She was an operational leader in acute, community and mental health care providers for more than 21 years and is passionate about improving care through the development of people and cultures. At Sheffield Teaching Hospitals she led the creation of the Sheffield Microsystem Coaching Academy in partnership with the Dartmouth Institute in Massachusetts, US.

Before joining the Fund, Suzie was the director of leadership and quality improvement at NHS Improvement, where her work included the design and delivery of the first national framework for improvement and leadership development in England and the creation of a major programme on culture and leadership with Professor Michael West and The King’s Fund.

Suzie is a trustee of Skills for Care, a Health Foundation fellow and on the editorial board of the Future Healthcare Journal.

Isabella works in the marketing team. She supports the promotion of The King’s Fund events programme and the marketing strategy for conferences and online events.

Before joining the Fund, Isabella worked in the technology marketing team at Accenture and gained communications experience working for a food waste charity and the Wellcome Trust. In 2017, she graduated from the University of York with a BA in philosophy. Her areas of interest include public health and the role of technology in health and care.

field_job_title.value: GP in Carnforth, Lancashire and Director of Population Health for the Morecambe Bay Health and Care System

body.value:
Dr Andy Knox is a GP in Carnforth, Lancashire and the Director of Population Health for the Morecambe Bay Health and Care System.

He is passionate about working with communities to tackle health inequalities and improve overall health and wellbeing. He is also focused on creating a culture of joy, kindness and excellence within the health and care system to support the health and wellbeing of teams.

He writes regularly on his blogs: reimagininghealth.com and reimaginingthefuture.org and can be followed on Facebook: Andrew James Knox, Twitter: @wellbeingandy, and YouTube: DrAndyKnox.

field_job_title.value: Chair, Gloucestershire Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust and Chair of Research4Gloucestershire

body.value:
Peter Lachecki is a former Non-Executive Director of Worcestershire Health & Care NHS Trust (2011–2016). He chaired the Quality & Safety Committee, was a member of the Audit Committee and was Deputy Chairman. He has been Chair at Gloucestershire Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust since November 2016, and is also Chair of Research4Gloucestershire.

His most senior appointment in a corporate role was as Global Category Director at Kraft Foods, where he led a complex group of internal functions including marketing, finance, sales and research and development. Peter is a qualified executive coach and continues to run his own coaching, team development and facilitation business.

Mark works in the leadership and organisational development team. He has extensive experience of delivering development interventions across the health and social care system.

Before joining The King’s Fund, Mark held a number of senior strategic roles within the NHS, UK civil service and local government. He has postgraduate qualifications in social work, executive coaching and group action learning, a Masters in leadership and is an experienced executive coach. He is a qualified British Psychological Society occupational testing practitioner and is accredited to use a wide variety of psychometrics tools.

Mark is a facilitator, educator and coach with experience in supporting strategic change, service improvement, leadership, and wider organisational development interventions. He is particularly interested in supporting teams and leaders that are operating within complex systems.

Harry is part of The King’s Fund IT infrastructure team, which looks after the Fund’s network and servers. His work involves maintaining and improving the technical environment at the Fund through existing and emerging technologies, and supporting the Fund with project work. Harry is interested in working with people and bringing them together with technology to enable them to meet the goals set by the business in the most efficient way possible.

Harry started work in the IT industry in 2014 at construction company Laing O’Rourke where he spent four years learning a range of business and IT skills, and began to specialise in networking and site implementations.

Andrew heads the external affairs team at The King’s Fund and is currently Joint Interim Director of Communications. He plays a strategic role in positioning the organisation, maintaining the Fund’s profile in the media and engaging key audiences. Andrew leads communications strategies and provide strategic communications advice to colleagues across the organisation.

Before joining The King’s Fund, Andrew was Head of Communications at National Voices, the coalition of health and care charities, where he oversaw the launch of a new website, the development of a new brand identity and a significant uplift in the organisation’s media profile.

Andrew’s previous roles include Head of PR and Communications at London South Bank University and Public Affairs Manager at the Royal College of Physicians.

Jen Thorley looks after the website, social media, digital projects, podcast and analytics. Her role includes developing and extending the Fund’s online presence as well as overseeing the production of digital content.

Jen worked in the Fund’s digital team between 2010 and 2014, joining again to lead the team in April 2018. In between, she worked in digital roles in the housing sector, and started her career in publishing at Condé Nast.

As part of the leadership and organisational development team, Karolina works on a number of the Fund’s commissioned programmes including The London North West Hospitals NHS Trust and Kettering General Hospital NHS Trust Leadership Development Programmes, Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital NHS Foundation Trust and Great Ormond Street Hospital NHS Foundation Trust Executive team development programmes and Doncaster Clinical Commissioning Group Building Collaborative Leadership programme.

Before joining The King’s Fund in Autumn 2017, Karolina worked at the ESCP Europe Business School coordinating a Masters in Management programme. Karolina has an MSc in Organisation and Management from the Warsaw University of Life Sciences.

Matthew’s role as Head of Commercial activities involves leading the Venue and Facilities teams. Matthew also manages the investment projects The King’s Fund undertakes in order to ensure our continued independence. 

Before joining The King’s Fund, Matthew worked for 20 years in luxury hospitality in London, country house and international hotels. Matthew holds a degree in International Hospitality Management.

field_job_title.value: Consultant Paediatrician, Bradford Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

body.value:
I have been a Consultant Paediatrician at the Bradford Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust since 2008. I competed my undergraduate training in Queens University in Belfast and my initial paediatric training in Cardiff. I came to Yorkshire in 2001.

A lot of my work is at the ‘coal face’ of acute general paediatrics. Over the past 10 years there has been a significant increase in demand on secondary care services. This is unsustainable. With changes to the workforce and developments in technology, the NHS is ripe for innovation and transformation of services. The need is greater than ever before.

In Bradford there is system level buy-in for improving quality and value with the shared vision that ‘the key to delivering effective and urgent care is ensuring that the whole system is designed to support self-care and community care at home, thereby reducing avoidable hospital admissions and facilitating timely early discharges’ (Institute for Innovation and Improvement). The future can be bright but is only sustainable through better networks and collaboration.

Shanice Dowman works in the Finance team and is responsible for managing the Fund’s sales ledger. Her role includes, but is not limited to, processing invoices, taking different forms of payment, bank reconciliation and credit control.

Before joining the Fund, Shanice has a proven track record of 6 years in Finance, previously working for another health organisation, Fortius Clinic.

It is with great sadness that we advise of the unexpected death of our valued colleague and friend, Ben Fuchs in March 2022 . If you would like to share your memories of him, please do contribute to this online book of condolence. 

Ben Fuchs was a Senior Consultant at The King’s Fund, and a practicing psychologist for over 25 years. He had a particular interest in developing systems leadership in health and care. He worked with hospitals, clinical commissioning groups (CCGs), community services, sustainability and transformation partnerships (STPs) and integrated care systems (ICSs), and health regulators to improve quality and collaboration across boundaries. He specialised in working with leaders and organisations facing strategic, financial and cultural challenges - often within a pressured environment of complexity and uncertainty. His work helped leaders to clarify the key issues, engage in crucial conversations, surface and resolve conflicts, build trust and increase agility. 

Prior to joining The King's Fund, Ben was faculty with Ashridge Business School’s NHS consulting practice. Ben also worked in the corporate sector and in international development, leading conflict resolution projects with former adversaries in Nicaragua and Northern Ireland.

Ben held a Masters degree in counselling psychology and post-graduate level professional training in coaching, facilitation, conflict resolution, appreciative inquiry, Harvard negotiation and supervision. Publications include: Do you have advantage blindness (Harvard Business Review), Can we talk about power?, and Working with fear and anxiety in healthcare.

Lord Victor Adebowale CBE is Chief Executive of Turning Point, a health and social care organisation providing services for people with complex needs, including those affected by substance misuse, mental ill-health and those with a learning disability.

Dr Navina Evans has been Chief Executive of Health Education England since October 2020. She was previously Chief Executive of East London NHS Foundation Trust. She also held a number of positions across the Trust including Director of Operations & Deputy CEO, Director for Mental Health, Lead Clinician Newham CAMHS and Clinical Director for Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services. She has worked in Medical Education at Barts and The London Medical School as Honorary Senior Lecturer, Associate Dean, and Academic Year Tutor. Her experience is in Psychiatry and Paediatrics, Dr Evans holds a MBBS, DCH and MRCPsych.

Hilary is an internationally acclaimed social entrepreneur whose work in communities around the world focuses on collaborative, affordable solutions to 21st century challenges: good work, care and health. Transformation is achieved through approaches that emphasise human relationships supported by technology.  

Hilary is a World Economic Forum Young Global Leader and was named UK Designer of the Year in 2005 for her pioneering work founding the practice of social design. Educated at Oxford, Sussex and the Open University, Hilary holds a PhD in social sciences. Her first book Radical Help was published in June 2018.

field_job_title.value: Head of Research and Engagement, Surrey County Council and Surrey Heartlands Health and Care Partnership

body.value:
As a social research specialist with 17 years' experience, Rich has spent much of his career at large research agencies such as Ipsos MORI and Kantar.

He joined Surrey County Council in 2014 to direct their social research programme and make the organisation more evidence focused. He has since taken on the additional role of Head of Research and Engagement at Surrey Heartlands Health and Care Partnership and is currently directing a programme of research and co-design with its citizens and staff aimed at transforming health and care services in Surrey.

As well as experience in social research, he has been extensively involved in research in other sectors including consumer goods, retail, finance and media.

Dr Kin Yee Shiu is a consultant in nephrology and acute/general medicine at the Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust. She is also clinical lead for chronic kidney disease and renal outpatients.

In 2017, Dr Kin Yee Shiu took part in our Leadership for consultants programme.

Tom is an academic GP trainee at Imperial College; he is working in the policy team at The King’s Fund for six months alongside a GP practice in Islington.

Having previously worked at NHS England and Public Health England, he is interested in the interface between general practice and public health. He is also working on patient satisfaction and the experience of stigma in the health system for people living with HIV.

Dr Charlotte Augst is currently on leave from her role as Richmond Group of Charities Partnership Director, which she has held for five years. She will take up the role of CEO for National Voices in March 2019. She has written this blog in a personal capacity.

Lisa McDonald works in the HR team and is responsible for developing and managing internal communications and staff engagement at the Fund.

Lisa is covering Vicky Ellen’s secondment until August 2019. Before joining the Fund, Lisa was Internal Communication Manager at both The Royal British Legion and PRS for Music. Prior to specialising in internal communication, Lisa held a number of communication roles working on national health campaigns such as No Smoking Day, Walk to School Week (for national sustainable travel charity Living Streets) and Don’t Lose the Music (a hearing health campaign aimed at young people, run by Action on Hearing Loss). Lisa has a postgraduate diploma in Internal Communications Management from Kingston University.

field_job_title.value: Primary care consultant and GP academic clinical fellow

body.value: Luke is a WHO primary care consultant and GP academic clinical fellow working in Oxford. He completed his MPH in global health at Harvard and works at the intersection of health, politics, and economics. He sits on the board of the Thames Valley RCGP faculty and the editorial board of the British Journal of General Practice.

Annie Whelan was the CEO of Seaview until September 2019. Seaview is a mental health and homeless charity on the south coast providing an open access wellbeing centre and rough sleeper outreach. She has also been one of the independent members of the National Information Board since its inception in 2014.

Annie spent 20 years living in the USA, where she worked with a street homeless service in Detroit. She was the Director for a crisis women’s service, and supported the development and opening of service-user run enterprises in two counties in central Ohio. 

After returning to England, Annie managed mental health advocacy services in a variety of settings; community, inpatient, forensic and prison. As Development Lead for the Association of Mental Health Providers for several years, Annie led on their work with the Department of Health Strategic Partners Programme.

In 2018, Seaview was one of eight winners of a GSK IMPACT Award. The awards are funded by GSK and run in partnership with The King’s Fund.

field_job_title.value: Chief Executive, Guy’s and St Thomas’ Charity

body.value:
Kieron Boyle has been Chief Executive of Guy’s and St Thomas’ Charity since 2016 and oversees all their work to improve health in urban communities.

Prior to joining the charity, he worked across the public sector, including at the Prime Minister’s Strategy Unit and Foreign and Commonwealth Office, and headed the UK government’s work on social innovation and investment. He began his career at the Boston Consulting Group.

Kieron sits on the boards of Big Society Capital, the world's first social investment bank, the Design Council and Catch22. He a is member of the Mayor of London’s Childhood Obesity Taskforce and chairs the Investment Committee of Nesta's Cultural Impact Development Fund.

Internationally, Kieron is on the advisory boards of the World Policy Institute and the Global Steering Group for Impact Investment. In 2014 he was selected as a Young Global Leader by the World Economic Forum.

Before joining the Fund, Sally had extensive experience in health, care and population health policy and delivery, in central and local government. Sally was Director for Social Care at the Department for Health and Social Care, Director of Programmes at Public Health England and Deputy Chief Inspector (for social care and registration) at the Care Quality Commission. She was also Director at the Cabinet Office, leading a project on social care funding for Budget 2017.

Most recently, Sally worked at the Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs as Director of the Agri-Food Chain, and latterly Director of EU Exit Preparedness and Response.

Kiran joined the leadership and organisational development team in April 2019. He has a broad experience of the health sector having held roles including acute service management, commissioning, provider capacity and capability building at national level, and as a strategy consultant. His most recent work prior to joining The King's Fund focused on provider leadership policy development, talent management, and increasing the professional diversity of board-level teams.

Kiran enjoys working with groups on their development and is an experienced facilitator, team coach and action learning facilitator. He has research interests in complexity and practice theory, and has been inquiring into relational perspectives on expertise, practitioner shame and ethics in organisation development.

Bryony works in the leadership and organisational development team and is responsible for co-ordinating a varied portfolio of open programmes and commissioned work with the Fund’s consultants.

Before joining the Fund, Bryony worked at Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew in the major donor fundraising events team, organising a variety of bespoke cultivation and stewardship events to showcase Kew’s scientific research tackling global challenges, such as climate change and food security.

Bryony works in the leadership and organisational development team and is responsible for co-ordinating a varied portfolio of open programmes and commissioned work with the Fund’s consultants.

Before joining the Fund, Bryony worked at Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew in the major donor fundraising events team, organising a variety of bespoke cultivation and stewardship events to showcase Kew’s scientific research tackling global challenges, such as climate change and food security.

field_job_title.value: Chair, NHS Improvement and Chair, National Workforce Implementation Steering Group
Chief People Officer, NHS England and NHS Improvement
Chief Executive, Arthur Rank Hospice Charity

body.value:
Lysette left the Fund in June 2023.
