As part of the leadership and organisational development team, Lysette works on a number of the Fund’s multidisciplinary programmes including quality improvement fellowship, medical leadership fellowship, leading collaboratively with patients and communities, managing GP productivity, public health trainees and the Top Manager programme.

Before joining the Fund, Lysette worked at the Multiple Sclerosis Society. She has a degree in international relations from the University of Sussex and a Masters in conflict, security and development.

Sarah joined The King’s Fund facilities team in May 2008 as a receptionist. Our reception consists of three receptionists, who are split over shifts 7.00am–9.00pm. My role includes welcoming staff, tenants and visitors into our building, answering the switchboard and dealing with people’s queries.

Before joining the Fund, I worked in various other customer service roles in London.

Emilija has left the Fund.

Emilija works in the leadership and organisational development team as a programme co-ordinator for various leadership development programmes including Clinical directors and lead clinicians, Leadership for consultants, Leading breakthrough conversations and Athena. She also provides various administrative support to the programme directors.

Prior to joining The King’s Fund in 2019, Emilija worked as Quality, Patient Safety and Commissioning Officer for Health Education England.

Jonathon left the Fund in November 2022. 

Jonathon joined The King's Fund in August 2019 as policy adviser. He sat within the responsive policy team and his work at the Fund was primarily external facing, looking to understand and identify key areas of policy that the Fund’s insight can help shape and influence.

Jonathon previously worked at Healthwatch England, where he led their work on social care, analysing public attitudes towards and understanding of the social care system in England. He also conducted focused policy work on hospital readmissions, dementia care, patient feedback and unpaid carer’s experiences of support services. Prior to this he held policy roles in the voluntary sector and the care provider sector.

Jo leads the business and operational side of the Leadership and Organisational Development team and is passionate about working with teams and organisations to support how they develop and support their staff to deliver high quality care.

Before joining The King’s Fund in 2019, Jo worked at NHS Improvement as the joint National Programme Director for the design and delivery of the first national framework for improvement and leadership development in England (2016). Alongside this, Jo managed a portfolio of programmes including the development of resources to support culture change in provider organisations. Jo has worked in various sectors over her career, including commercial, charity and the public sector (education, health and social care). Over the past 18 years she has worked with policy and development teams at a national level to support capability building across the education sector and the NHS.

Jo holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Sociology and Social Psychology and a postgraduate diploma.

Megan is currently on sabbatical.

Megan works in the communications team and is responsible for managing the publications schedule and editorial processes for The King’s Fund reports and digital outputs.

Prior to joining The King’s Fund in September 2018, Megan worked as a development editor for Hodder Education, a commercial education publisher, where her role involved providing support to authors and editing resources for the further education and international schools markets.

title.value: Rt. Hon. Professor the Lord Ajay Kakkar KBE PC

body.value:
Rt. Hon. Professor the Lord Kakkar is Professor of Surgery at University College London, Chairman of UCLPartners Academic Health Science Partnership, and Director of the Thrombosis Research Institute, London.

He completed his medical degree from King’s College London and received his PhD from Imperial College London. He has been a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons since 1992. His research interests include the prevention and treatment of venous and arterial thromboembolic disease, and cancer-associated thrombosis.

Lord Kakkar was made a life peer in 2010 and sits on the crossbenches of the House of Lords. He was Chairman of the House of Lords Appointments Commission from 2013–2018. He is a member of Her Majesty’s Most Honourable Privy Council and is Chairman of the Judicial Appointments Commission.

He began his role as Chair in January 2020.

field_job_title.value: Chief Executive, Tū Ora Compass Health

body.value: Martin Hefford is chief executive of Tū Ora Compass Health, a primary health organisation in New Zealand. He has been on a 12-week sabbatical hosted by The King’s Fund and the Birmingham Health Services Management Centre. During his sabbatical, he met with NHS clinicians and managers from across England – from Torbay to Manchester, as well as Scotland, Denmark and Macedonia, looking at primary care challenges and innovations.

Ethan has left the Fund.

Ethan is a researcher in the policy team. His particular areas of interest include population health, health inequalities and the social determinants of health.

Before joining The King’s Fund, Ethan worked as a management consultant at the Good Governance Institute, supporting NHS providers on a range of projects covering clinical and corporate governance, strategy development and organisational change. He holds an MPhil in politics from the University of Oxford.

Ethan is a trustee of the Rural Urban Synthesis Society, a community land trust that builds sustainable, affordable homes in London. He also works as a mentor for ex-prisoners.

Becca supports digital communications activity across The King’s Fund’s website and social media channels. She is responsible for creating, editing and publishing a range of digital content, overseeing the Fund’s Facebook and LinkedIn accounts, and managing the Weekly Update newsletter.

Before joining the Fund in April 2019, Becca worked as an editor for a digital publishing platform, managing projects across a wide range of sectors including health, education and the third sector. She also has previous experience in digital marketing and website management.

Emma works on the Fund’s digital content and online presence. She supports the team in her work on the social media and digital marketing strategies, as well as working as the digital lead for a range of publications and projects.

Before joining the Fund, Emma worked as a freelance consultant helping charities reach their audiences and drive engagement through social and digital media.

Rachel is a director in Ipsos MORI’s health and social care team, leading on NHS workforce and regulator research and evaluation. She recently directed the evaluation of revalidation among nurses and midwives for the National Midwifery Council, and has previously carried out research for the British Medical Association on what matters to doctors when making job choices. She has also directed several projects on recruiting and retaining staff for NHS England, including research with GPs to inform the development of the General practice forward view and work on the drivers and barriers to general practice nursing.

Rachel has more than 14 years’ experience as a mixed-method researcher across both the health and criminal justice sectors. Before joining Ipsos MORI in 2007, she was part of the research team at Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Prisons, sparking her interest in inspection and regulation. She has also previously worked as a primary school teacher.

Born and educated in London, Lena brings extensive health sector experience to her current roles as Chair of the Hampshire and Isle of White Sustainability and Transformation Partnership and as Chair of South Central Ambulance Service. She was previously a non-executive director with University Hospital Southampton and an associate non-executive director with Isle of White NHS Trust. She was a lay advisor with Wessex Deanery where she undertook GP recruitment and the assessment of post-graduate doctors in rotation. She also sat on the school boards of surgery and emergency medicine.

She started her career as a lecturer in further and higher education, and managed a training centre in London for young people at risk of exclusion. She currently runs a company providing communications and training in leadership, human rights and child protection on behalf of organisations such as the National Crime Agency, UNICEF and UN Women. In addition, Lena is a Governor at Southampton Solent University.

Harry works in the press and public affairs team at The King’s Fund. He is responsible for securing media coverage for the Fund’s work, including the GSK IMPACT Awards, and working with stakeholders in the health and care sector.

Before joining the Fund in 2019, Harry led the press team at the Francis Crick Institute, the UK’s largest biomedical research institute. He previously managed media relations for the health and science faculties of major UK universities including UCL and the University of Oxford.

Rebecca works in the events and partnerships team, developing the Fund’s corporate partnerships programme. Before joining the Fund in 2020, Rebecca spent three years managing events in health and educational charities, most recently at Macmillan Cancer Support, where she managed events focused on research, health data and policy. Before this Rebecca worked in the social care sector, managing new business, measuring performance and quality, and managing services for adults with learning disabilities.

Chloe works within the Fund’s corporate partnership team, managing and growing mutually beneficial relationships with our partner businesses, while protecting the Fund’s reputation for independence and quality in line with our ethical partnerships policy.

Her role includes building strategic relationships with potential new corporate partners and supporters, and developing partner events, including seminars, dinners and briefings. Her areas of interest include mental health and the role of technology in health and care. Before joining the Fund, Chloe launched a business-to-business event in Amsterdam. She has an English literature and history Masters from the University of Edinburgh.

Gbemi Babalola was a senior analyst in the policy team at The King's Fund on a secondment from the Department of Health and Social Care. In this role, Gbemi supported a variety of research projects mainly through quantitative analysis and effective communication of complex data. Work areas included social care and NHS performance in the acute sector.

Gbemi is an economist at the Department of Health and Social Care,  returning to this role in autumn 2020. She works on various projects including workforce modelling and the relationship between work and health. Gbemi has an MSc in Health Economics, specialising in economic evaluation, and previous experience working for NHS England.

field_job_title.value: Director and Professor of Social Policy, Centre for Housing Policy, University of York

body.value:
Simon is part of the leadership and organisation development team and has 20 years’ experience working in a variety of frontline and leadership roles across children’s and adult mental health services, public health, education and social care. Beginning his career in community development, he was more recently chief executive of an award-winning youth mental health charity for nine years. Simon joined The King’s Fund from Roffey Park Institute, where he designed and delivered leadership and organisation development programmes for clients across the public, private and voluntary and community sectors.

Simon is a cultural anthropologist and sociologist by training, and is interested in the role of culture and power in shaping professional practice and public service cultures, particularly where this relates to wider health and institutional inequalities. An experienced coach, consultant and facilitator of action learning and participatory social research, he is also a social entrepreneur skilled in using social design methods to produce creative, human-centred services and learning and development experiences.

field_job_title.value: Professor of Care of Older People, University of Nottingham

body.value: Adam Gordon is Professor of Care of Older People, University of Nottingham, and Vice President for Academic Affairs, British Geriatrics Society. He has been a care home researcher for more than a decade. Adam currently runs a Covid-19 ward.

field_job_title.value: Professor of Health Care Research, University of Hertfordshire

body.value: Claire Goodman is Professor of Health Care Research, University of Hertfordshire, a nurse and a NIHR senior investigator. She has led a substantial programme of care home research. Claire is currently the lead investigator for the NIHR DACHA (developing research resources and minimum data set for care homes' adoption and use) study.

Lindsey has more than 25 years of international OD consulting experience and her particular interests are in supporting organisations and leaders in complex and uncertain environments through change, through designing and delivering a wide range of leadership and OD interventions.

She is able to offer practical experience (having led the Corporate business at Ashridge Business School) and can apply leading-edge theory to the everyday process of engaging teams in times of change together with the pragmatic skills of authentic and effective leadership. She is also an Ashridge-accredited coach where she focuses on working as a thinking partner for senior leaders in supporting them to become more reflective and mindful of their leadership practice.

Lindsey works in the UK and internationally in sectors including health, financial services, public sector, IT, retail, professional services, manufacturing, pharmaceuticals and utilities.

Mark Britnell is Visiting Professor at the new Global Business School for Health at UCL and Senior Fellow and Executive-in-Residence at the Sandra Rotman School of Management at the University of Toronto. He was vice chair of KPMG UK until the end of December 2022 and before that was Global Chairman and Senior Partner for Healthcare, Government and Infrastructure at KPMG International.

He is one of the foremost global experts on healthcare systems and has dedicated his entire professional life to healthcare, having led organisations at local, regional, national and global levels.

In 2000, Mark was appointed Chief Executive of University Hospitals Birmingham, where he masterminded the largest new hospital build in NHS history, established the Royal Centre for Defence Medicine and developed one of the highest performing healthcare organisations in the UK.

He went on to run the NHS South Central region before joining the NHS management board as Director General at the Department of Health, where he developed High Quality Care for All, the final report of the NHS Next Steps Review, with Lord Darzi.

Between 2014 and 2018, Mark sat as a member of the Global Agenda Council on the Future of the Health Sector for the World Economic Forum and sits on the Advisory Board of the China Center for Health Development at Peking University. Mark is the author of In search of the perfect health system and Human: solving the global workforce crisis in healthcare.

Clair left The Fund in March 2023.

Clair is a researcher in the policy team. Her areas of interest include population health, patient involvement and experience, and health inequalities.

Before joining The King’s Fund, Clair worked for Healthwatch across three London boroughs where she led their policy and research functions and supported the representation of patient voices in local decision-making. She holds an MSc in social policy and social research from University College London.

She undertakes the lead chief executive role for Greater Manchester on a range of issues including the Safe and Stronger Communities portfolio. She is the architect for the Greater Manchester Leadership and Workforce Development Framework, which aims to support the growth of a community of skilled and connected leaders from all sectors in the city region. She is the lead chief executive for Greater Manchester Population Health Board, overseeing the wellbeing and prevention agenda for the area. In addition, she sits on the Oldham Maggie’s Fundraising Board and is co-chair of the Greater Manchester Cancer Board. She was appointed to the NHS Assembly in March 2019.

She has significant public sector experience, and a long-time commitment to understanding public service delivery from different perspectives. This includes involvement in the Civil Society Future Inquiry and the Centre for Policing Research and Learning at the Open University.

Carolyn has a Masters in Literature from the Open University and a Masters in Public Administration from Warwick Business School. Her Doctorate in Business Administration focused on the relationship between trust and control in organisations during times of significant change.

Carolyn was awarded an OBE in June 2016 for her services to local government and public service reform.

See our interview with Carolyn Wilkins on place-based leadership >

Donata has more than 25 years’ experience as an organisational and leadership development consultant. She works with integrity, honesty and commitment to ensure individuals and organisations achieve the improvements they seek in a sustainable way.

An internationally recognised dialogue consultant and practitioner, Donata applies dialogue and structural dynamics theory and processes throughout her practice. She considers dialogue to be the cornerstone for achieving breakthrough in the unhelpful

Donata’s clients include local and central government, the Ministry of Defence, the police, health care organisations, NHS Education Scotland, Rolls Royce, John Lewis Partnership and local charities. Coaching assignments include supporting directors and chief officers to understand the dynamics of their environment, diagnose leadership development and organisational needs, and designing and delivering unique programmes of development. Donata works with board members in fractured relationships move forward in a positive and restored way.

field_job_title.value: Consultant Liaison Psychiatrist at the South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust

body.value:
Dr Mary Docherty is a Consultant Liaison Psychiatrist at the South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust working in St Thomas’s Hospital and King’s College Hospital.

Her background includes training in social sciences and organisational consultancy. She has held policy roles with the Department of Health, NHS England, the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE), and London’s Healthy London Partnership working on national and regional programs tackling inefficiencies and inequalities at service interfaces for individuals living with mental ill health. She has policy, research and clinical expertise in service integration including research in integrated mental, physical and social care as a former Harkness Fellow in Health Care Policy at Columbia University, New York.

field_job_title.value: Head of Inclusive System Development, NHS England and Improvement

body.value:
Tracie Jolliff is national Head of Inclusive System Development at NHS England and Improvement. She strategically leads the inclusion portfolio of work for Leadership and Life-long Learning.

Tracie facilitates the design and development of effective and ethical leadership strategies, which have at their heart justice, inclusion and sustainability.  She’s an experienced executive coach and has spoken and lectured on leadership and inclusion nationally, working with government representatives and other bodies to address these themes across the public sector.

field_job_title.value: Interim Director, NHS Workforce Race Equality Standard NHS England

body.value:
Dr Habib Naqvi is the Interim Director for the NHS Workforce Race Equality Standard at NHS England. He has a background in public health, health psychology, health care policy and strategy development.

Before joining NHS England in 2013, Habib led on the development of national equality and diversity policy at the Department of Health and Social Care, including leading on the health sector’s response to the UK government’s review of the Public Sector Equality Duty.

Habib is a member of several national advisory bodies and an ambassador for the Mary Seacole Trust. He is reverse mentoring the NHS Chief Executive, Sir Simon Stevens, and was awarded an MBE in the 2019 Queen’s Birthday Honours for services to equality and diversity in the NHS.

Dr Malasi practises from Dashwood Medical Practice, Kent, and started his medical career at Margate’s QEQM hospital. 

Dr Malasi has a particular interest in deprivation and mental health. He gained Section 12 Approval post MRCGP qualification (Membership of the Royal College of General Practitioners), and has worked in psychiatric intensive care, substance misuse and memory clinics. 

A Yale Global Health Initiative alumnus, he is Thanet CCG ex-Clinical Chair and commissioner for Mental Health, Learning Disabilities and Dementia. 

Dr Malasi also has a background in emergency sports medicine, with 10 years international experience as a sports medic. He is currently pursuing a degree in health economics at the London School of Economics.

Pritesh works in the policy team where he focuses on how digital tools and technologies can improve health and care. He is particularly passionate about using evidence-based digital technology as an enabler to improve quality of care and outcomes while critically assessing buzzwords and technology as a silver bullet. Pritesh combines his understanding of technology with the broader picture of the essential ingredients needed for digital change to have an impact. This encompasses culture, unmet need, infrastructure, change management and knowledge all to improve quality, inequalities and outcomes.

Before joining the Fund, Pritesh led the innovation activity at the Royal College of General Practitioners encompassing system change, entrepreneurship, grassroots innovation and horizon-scanning. Before this he worked at Guy’s and St Thomas’ NHS Trust helping to bring together clinicians and patients with research and technology to improve the care and outcomes of people with life-debilitating conditions such as heart failure.

field_job_title.value: Strategic Lead for Organisational Development and System Leadership, Greater Manchester Health and Social Care Partnership

body.value:
John is the Strategic Lead for Organisational Development and System Leadership in the Greater Manchester Health and Social Care Partnership and spends his time working on culture, leadership, equality and inclusion across public services in Greater Manchester. Key to his role has been addressing the leadership and cultural challenges of implementing the GM Mayor’s vision for a One Workforce approach to public services across the Greater Manchester devolved region. John also leads on the commitment across Greater Manchester public services in addressing Race Equality across the workforce, and commissioned the work to create change in experience and outcome for BAME people in public services – this was the first project of its kind in the UK.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, John was redeployed as the Deputy Director of Workforce for NHS Nightingale North West. He worked on key areas in regard to recruitment, induction, culture and health and wellbeing of the staff and patients.

field_job_title.value: Chief Nurse at Buckinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust

body.value:
Karen is the Chief Nurse at Buckinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust. In her 25 years qualified nursing career, Karen has worked in a number of large and complex NHS organisations in London. She holds a diploma along with a BSc degree in Nursing and a MSc in advanced practice leadership from Kings College University. She is a graduate from the NHS Leadership Academy Senior Leaders and Nye Bevan programme for aspiring directors.

Karen is a member of the Workforce Race Equality Standard (WRES) strategic advisory group and works with the Prostate Cancer UK, to educate and raise awareness of the disease.

Karen recently stepped down as a trustee of the Mary Seacole Trust where she led the diversity in leadership programme and was highly commended by the Nursing Times in 2019 for her work in diversity and inclusion.

Aamena is an academic GP trainee at Imperial College who joined The King’s Fund health policy team for six months as part of her training in August 2020.

Prior to starting her GP training she worked as a National Medical Director’s Clinical Fellow and spent a year of leading on quality improvement programmes at Chelsea and Westminster Foundation Trust as a Clinical Improvement and Innovation Fellow.

She undertook her medical training at the University of Cambridge and has a BA in Psychology from the same university.

Laura works in the policy team. Before joining the Fund in 2020, Laura worked in various academic health research departments, including the University of Bradford, Bradford Institute for Health Research and Cambridge Institute for Public Health.

During her career, Laura has worked on projects promoting physical activity, medication adherence and healthy eating in regional or primary care settings as well as quality improvement projects in hospital settings. Laura has an MPhil in Public Health from the University of Bradford, which looked at physical activity promotion apps that provided feedback on user affect.

Michael Alexander is a locum doctor in London, most recently working in forensic psychiatry and with an interest in public health. He is also the Treasurer of GLADD, the Association of LGBTQ+ Doctors and Dentists.

Charlotte joined The King's Fund in May 2021 as a policy adviser. She sits within the responsive policy team and her work at the Fund is primarily external facing, identifying, analysing and communicating emerging policy issues.

Charlotte previously worked at Anthony Nolan, where she led work on access to treatments, with a focus on understanding the changes to the access landscape resulting from the review of National Institute for Health and Care Excellence’s (NICE) methods. She also conducted focused policy work on blood cancer data, a strategy for the next 10 years of stem cell transplantation and patient experience of the Covid-19 pandemic. Prior to this she held roles at Macmillan Cancer Support and the Office of the Children’s Commissioner for England. She has an International Security Masters from the University of Sussex.

Toby undertakes research and policy analysis at The King’s Fund, focused on health inequalities and poverty. He contributes to The King’s Fund’s work on integrated care and health system reform, and has a particular interest in how the NHS can contribute to local regeneration and to changing disparities of outcome.

Before joining The King's Fund, Toby worked in the health services for more than 25 years at an operational level in mental health, primary care and hospital services. He has held director roles across University College London Hospital, Mid Yorkshire Hospitals NHS Trust, Bart’s Health NHS Trust, and was Chief Executive of Sandwell and West Birmingham Hospitals until 2021. He worked in the Prime Minister’s Delivery Unit from 2003–5, graduated from the Fund’s Top Manager programme in 2004, and holds degrees from the University of Oxford and the University of London.
body.summary: Biography of Toby Lewis, Senior Fellow, Policy

body.value:
Lizzie left the Fund in August 2022. 

Lizzie supports digital communications activity across The King’s Fund’s website, email platform and social media channels. She is responsible for creating, editing and publishing a range of digital content, including oversight of the Fund’s Facebook and LinkedIn accounts and the weekly update newsletter.

Before joining the Fund in June 2021, Lizzie worked as a social media manager for a creative advertising agency, managing campaigns for both government and third sector clients. She has a Masters in political communication from the University of Sheffield.

Danielle is an analyst in the policy team and works with data from across the health and social care landscape. She has a particular interest in health inequalities.

Before joining the Fund, Danielle worked at a management consulting company specialising in health care. She has worked on several transformational projects in NHS hospitals and ambulance services in England, which included quantitative analysis as well as on-the-ground change management.

Sophie works in the press and public affairs team and is responsible for ensuring the Fund’s communications deliver maximum impact by supporting media relations and public affairs work, and digital communications. She works on high-profile issues and engages directly with journalists, social media audiences, and expert colleagues at the Fund.

Before joining the Fund in 2021, Sophie worked for the NHS at the Royal Brompton Hospital where she was involved in a number of transformation and engagement projects. She also gained experience in internal and external communications, working with a range of stakeholders across the organisation.

Emily left the Fund in April 2022.

Emily was a researcher in the policy team. Her research interests include anti-racism and anti-oppressive practice, health equity, mental health and approaches centred on lived experience.

Before joining the Fund, Emily was a policy analyst for NHS England and NHS Improvement. Before she moved to London, Emily worked in Canada in a variety of sectors, including municipal government and nonprofit-based community development.

She holds a Master in public health, with a focus on health promotion, from the University of Alberta.

Ana left the Fund in December 2022. 

Ana Lekaj joined The King’s Fund as the Senior Programme Co-ordinator to support the delivery of the Healthy Communities Together programme, which is delivered in partnership with The National Lottery Community Fund.

Ana has been working across the statutory, voluntary and community sectors for 20 years delivering children’s and community services and working for a mental health voluntary regulator. More recently, she took up a programme support role at Public Health England in the health improvement directorate, within the children, young people and families and healthy ageing teams. She also led on setting up a local London Healthwatch after a recommissioning process.

Ana holds a recent postgraduate degree from Central St Martins, University of Arts London, in Arts and Cultural Enterprise, where she completed her dissertation in arts in health, looking at innovative and ground-breaking social prescribing policies and practices in clinical, community and cultural settings.

Judith Osorio is a programme co-ordinator in the leadership and organisational development team, working across a variety of open programmes, commissioned pieces of work and other projects.

Before joining the Fund in 2021, Judith worked as an events manager within the charity sector, organising large-scale fundraising and networking events. Prior to this she held operational roles within the conference sector and travel industry, providing a wealth of organisational and planning experience.

Jane joined The Fund in March 2021 to create and lead a fresh marketing function focused on brand, relationship marketing and customer insight. She is passionate about using marketing skills to help improve health and social care and protecting and evolving The King's Fund brand.

She is a senior marketing communications and business professional with over 25 years' global experience in both consultancies and client-side, and across sectors, cultures and disciplines.

She has previously worked at a number of values-based organisations including, The Co-operative Group, The John Lewis Partnership and the original Nudge Unit.

Angela Fell is the Managing Director of RIPEN. She provides workshops for professionals who work alongside people who feel ambivalent about change, specialising in hosting space where professionals from multi-disciplinary contexts can learn together.  

She is cofounder of the Movement for Neighbourhood Democracy and a trainer for Nurture Development, hosting asset based community development discovery programmes. She is a director of Northern Heart and Soul – a newly formed Wigan-based community interest company that seeks to rekindle the function of communities and create self managing and renovating neighbourhoods.

Hari left the Fund in November 2022. 

Hari works within the Fund’s finance and operations directorate as Head of Operations, working to improve business processes at the Fund including oversight of strategic and operational planning and risk management.

Before joining the Fund, Hari worked with for- and non-profit organisations in research, programme management, business development and strategy, and has a Masters in Medical Anthropology from University College London with focus on metrics and measurement.

Dean Samways works across the digital and marketing teams. He is responsible for developing and implementing email marketing strategies for the leadership team, as well as some digital content projects from all over The King’s Fund.

Before joining the Fund in his interim role in 2021, Dean spent many successful years contracting as a digital content professional for a number of brands including Which?, University College London and Microsoft; building and rolling out omnichannel content strategies. He has a Bachelor’s degree in journalism from Southampton Solent University.

Toby is an organisational development and change consultant working with teams, organisations and systems to help sense-making, development, and strategic focus and action. He has a deep interest in the work of collaboration and integration and how people work with, and acknowledge, power to enable that to happen.

Toby has worked on projects supporting the integration of health and social care across North Wales; supporting a group of clinical commissioning groups in preparing for and moving into the integrated care system landscape; and delivering leadership development in an acute trust, enabled by innovative digital design and delivery.

He has a Masters in people and organisational development and is currently studying for his PhD. Research-informed practice and practice-informed research are his passions and he works in partnership with clients to co-design work packages that support and enable participants and the systems and organisations they work in.

Louise joined The King’s Fund in January in 2021, as Head of Events and Partnerships (maternity leave cover).

Before moving to London, Louise worked in Brussels for many years, first in the press team at the Swedish Representation to the EU and later joining the event team at the European Wind Energy Association.

Most recently, Louise worked as Head of Experience Design at the consultancy Xynteo where she also travelled the globe organising leadership events.

Dr Sonya Wallbank is a consultant clinical psychologist and specialises in workforce resilience and restorative approaches to wellbeing. She has worked in the NHS as a director of service delivery and workforce, leading complex change and improvement programmes for NHS England and NHS Improvement, including the delivery of the health and wellbeing response for NHS staff during the Covid-19 pandemic.

She has also led HR services and operating model change for the Department of Health and Social Care and worked directly with organisations, teams and individuals wanting to change how they work in the UK, Australia and the US. She has authored materials to enable organisations to embed their own approach to restorative supervision. Sonya lectures on how focusing supervision and support on the needs of the individual, not just the work they deliver reduces stress, burnout and improves the pleasure people derive from their work.

Paula left the Fund in 2021.

Paula was a senior fellow at The King's Fund where her work focused on clinical and professional leadership and provider collaboratives. She is passionate about people working in healthy organisational and system cultures in support of the improved delivery of health and care.

Paula is an experienced chief executive and before joining The King's Fund had been chief executive at University Hospital Southampton, at Royal Surrey NHS Foundation Trust and at Sussex Community NHS Foundation Trust. In other roles in the NHS she has worked as executive lead for two cancer alliances; been a director of transformation in acute services and worked as a director of commissioning in primary care trusts. She started her career as a pharmacist and operational manager.

field_job_title.value: Charity Coordinator (CEO equivalent), My Life My Choice (MLMC)

body.value:
MLMC is an independent, multi-award-winning, 100-per-cent-user-led charity with 623 members with a learning disability from across Oxfordshire. As well as promoting choice, empowerment and participation, MLMC provides campaigning, volunteering, training, social and paid work opportunities supported by 11 staff and 60 volunteers.

Charity turnover: £250–500,000

Where the charity operates: South East

Bryan has been the charity leader at MLMC since 2012, responsible for governance, HR and management, project oversight, fundraising, strategy, and business development. Before joining MLMC Bryan was the Country Director for Raleigh International, a youth development charity operating in Central America, where he led volunteer teams of more than 50 staff supporting 150 young people. Bryan also held a role as the Director of Diversity and Equality Training for HMRC.

Bryan works at MLMC because it is truly 100 per cent user led (all 15 trustees have a learning disability). His work provides him with challenge, uncertainty, risk, opportunities to achieve practical results, and for innovation. ‘Supporting beneficiaries to achieve more than was ever thought possible continually inspires me.’

Areas of work: relational development; board strategy and development; strategic influencing; organisational development.

field_job_title.value: Chief Operating Officer, Autism at Kingwood

body.value:
Autsim at Kingwood provides specialist support to about 130 autistic adults and has 250 staff. The organisation provides supported living for people with autism and people with Asperger syndrome, helping them to live successfully in their own homes across Berkshire, Oxfordshire, Buckinghamshire and Wiltshire.

Charity turnover: more than £1 million

Where the charity operates: South East

As Chief Operating Officer of the organisation, Estelle’s responsibilities include the oversight of arrangements for 130 people and 250 staff as well as operational management and leadership to deliver great support and offer high-quality services. She also supports the organisation to develop new partnerships and generate collaborative working with other agencies to benefit the lives and future of the people Autism at Kingswood supports.

Estelle is passionate about leadership and the ability to have impact and helping others grow both personally and professionally through coaching and support.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; relational development; strategic influencing.

Age UK Wirral has more than 150 dedicated staff and around 700 volunteers helping to make later life a fulfilling and enjoyable experience. With a turnover of approximately £3.5m per annum, the organisation reaches more than 30,000 people locally each year through a range of community-based care and support services and regulated care services.

Charity turnover: more than £1 million

Where the charity operates: North West

Jamie has extensive coaching and mentoring experience across all areas of leadership with particular emphasis on supporting change management and exploring imposter syndrome. With more than 20 years' experience of senior leadership in the voluntary and community sector, Jamie has extensive knowledge particularly around older people's services. He is a person-centred and authentic leader, passionate about leadership and management development and support. He is also a chartered manager and a companion of the Chartered Management Institute. 

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; relational development; strategic influencing; board strategy and development.

WILD works with young mums, young dads, and their babies in Cornwall. The project offers groupwork, individual family support, help with care proceedings, music and arts projects, and parent and child relationship support. In 2020, it worked with 378 families. It has 30 staff.

Charity turnover: £500,000–1 million

Where the charity operates: South West

Jo has 35 years’ experience in the voluntary and community sector (VCS). She specialises in vision and future planning, fundraising, collaborative working, and safeguarding. Jo sits on several strategic partnership groups, and enjoys shaking things up to create change.

Jo works in this sector for the same reasons she did as a young volunteer 35 years ago – social justice, equality and hope. ‘I like to be bold and creative in tackling problems, and I do love an underdog!... The Covid-19 pandemic has hit everyone hard, and VCS work is more crucial than ever.’

Areas of work: organisational development; strategic influencing; relational development; change management.

BWC has been supporting women in Sussex since 1974. It is run for women by women with 26 staff and 40 volunteers. Services aim to reduce the wider determinants of health inequalities for women. The organisation supports women at risk or who have faced abuse including trauma, poverty and homelessness.

Charity turnover: £500,000–1 million

Where the charity operates: South East

Lisa has been the Director of BWC for 13 years. She has seen the organisation through transformative changes, from a six-fold growth in business development and income, to streamlining through the austerity cuts to re-building services by implementing a change programme.

Relationships are key and particularly co-production. ‘As a leader it is tough to be humble, not assume I hold the answers.’ The challenges presented by the Covid-19 pandemic have taught her how to 'hold' a safe space for colleagues to make sense of the work that leads to new ways of working.

Areas of work: relational development; change management; organisational development.

Every-One is a Lincolnshire-based charity focusing on ‘making wellbeing personal’ for people. It works at both an operational and a strategic level focusing on person-centred approaches, co-production and carer awareness. The charity facilitates volunteer-led projects, and offers training and network support. It has a small team but makes a big impact.

Charity turnover: up to £250,000

Where the charity operates: East Midlands

After starting her career in dance and qualifying as a primary school teacher, Vicky worked in local government as Assistant Director and Monitoring Officer for two local authorities leading work in their legal, democratic, elections, performance and communications functions. Joining Every-One as Chief Executive in 2015 she shaped the charity’s new direction.

Vicky is driven to influence policy and practice by working with people with lived experience to positively shape services. It is important to Vicky that people are supported to reach their potential, both within their wellbeing and their work. Her life motto is ‘Every day is a school day.’

Areas of work: board strategy and development; relational development; organisational development; change management; strategic influencing.

field_job_title.value: Chief Officer, Witton Lodge Community Association

body.value:
Witton Lodge Community Association is a dynamic social enterprise, providing housing, health, employment, and enterprise-related services to communities across Birmingham. The Association is growing and has a turnover of approx £2 million, employs 30 staff, and has a similar number of volunteers. Associates also offer consultancy support across the Midlands.

Charity turnover: more than £1 million

Where the charity operates: West Midlands

Since joining the Association in 2012, Afzal has worked with the board to shape strategic priorities, establish new partnerships and services, recruit teams, enhance financial viability and deepen impact. He has also held senior regeneration posts in local government with extensive experience of funding, commissioning and navigating the political environment.

Afzal is a passionate advocate of community-led approaches. While Covid-19 has created unprecedented challenges, it has also demonstrated the power of community. ‘As leaders of community and voluntary organisations we have the opportunity to work through the issues and emerge stronger.’ Afzal’s skills include relationship building; engaging and influencing stakeholders; business development, growth, and resilience; and coaching, developing and leading teams especially through change.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; strategic influencing; relational development; board strategy and development.

MAP is a youth charity in the east of England providing advice, counselling and youth work services focusing on youth rights and mental health. It works across NHS children and adolescent mental health services and youth-led teams dedicated to ensuring young people have a say over services and change in their community. MAP helped set up the Young Activist Network. It employs about 100 staff and has about 12 volunteers, including trainee counsellors.

Charity turnover: more than £1 million

Where the charity operates: East of England

Dan has been in charity leadership positions for 20 years. He is currently the Chief Executive of MAP, and previously worked for charities focusing on mental health, substance misuse and homelessness. He is a trustee of Youth Access and a school governor. He sits on various local boards and partnerships, including the local health and wellbeing board, and is the elected chair of the voluntary and community sector forum. Dan also works as an executive coach.

Dan is driven by values, in particular a commitment to social justice and the worth of every individual. In his coaching practice, he motivates people to overcome personal barriers and help develop the best solutions. Dan’s experience lies in NHS and local authority commissioning, strategic planning, income generation, people management and working with trustees. He particularly enjoys working with people newer to senior leadership but has helped old hands too. He also enjoys being coached.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; strategic influencing; relational development; board strategy and development.

field_job_title.value: Health & Wellbeing Associate, VONNE (Voluntary Organisations Network North East)

body.value:
VONNE is the voluntary and community sector infrastructure support organisation in north-east England and provides representation, sector knowledge and intelligence, capacity building, and communication and engagement for its members, bulletin subscribers, funders and stakeholder networks. The organisation has 15 staff.

Charity turnover: £500,000–1 million

Where the charity operates: North East

Jane is the health and wellbeing lead and former Chief Executive of VONNE and of Pioneering Care Partnership. She is currently the lead for the North East and North Cumbria Voluntary and Community Sector (VCS) Partnership Programme, supporting VCS engagement in integrated care systems, NHSE Regional Social Prescribing facilitator and NASP Thriving Communities Regional Lead. She has experience as a VCSE consultant and holds a ILM level-5 certificate in coaching and mentoring.

As a coach involved in the Cascading Leadership programme and as a qualified coach and mentor she can bring her learning to support and mentor senior VCS leaders. She feels that her experience can be particularly valuable in these unprecedented and challenging times.

Areas of work: strategic influencing; relational development; change management; organisational development; board strategy and development.

field_job_title.value: Chief Executive Officer, Womankind Bristol Women's Therapy Centre

body.value:
Womankind’s was set up in 1986 and it supports women to improve their mental health and wellbeing, to enable them to experience a better quality of life. The organisation provides a range of high-quality and trauma-informed therapeutic services. It has 25 staff and 70 volunteers.

Womankind’s telephone and webchat helpline handles more than 5,000 calls a year; one-third of women who contact the charity have suffered sexual abuse/assault, rape, or domestic abuse. Services include specialist counselling for survivors of sexual violence, trauma counselling for asylum seekers, refugees and Deaf women, outreach therapy, group therapy and a befriending service.

Charity turnover: £250–500,000

Where the charity operates: South West

Kyra has been Chief Executive of Womankind Bristol for 18 years and is strongly committed to women’s issues. She is an advocate of collaborative working and has a supportive and consultative leadership/coaching style. She recognises and highlights how the pressures created by Covid-19 have increased management of safeguarding/risk, mental health crisis and increased demand, staff wellbeing and financial pressures.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; strategic influencing; relational development; board strategy and development.

field_job_title.value: Chief Executive, New Outlook Housing Association

body.value:
New Outlook is a small specialist registered housing and care provider supporting people with a visual impairment or other specialist need, across the West Midlands. The organisation supports more than 180 people in a diverse range of accommodation including housing with care, supported living and small care homes

Charity turnover: more than £1m

Where the charity operates: West Midlands

Lydia has substantial senior experience within health, housing and social care having worked in the statutory and independent sector as a commissioner and provider of services. Lydia is a registered social worker, has a Masters in health and social care partnerships, and a Diploma in executive coaching and mentoring.

Lydia enjoys the challenge that leading a small organisation offers and strives to create a supportive and enjoyable work culture that empowers people to deliver the best personalised services possible. Lydia loves working as part of a team to help people achieve their aspirations whatever they may be.

Areas of work: change management; strategic influencing; board strategy and development; relational development; organisational development.

Gaddum is Manchester and Salford's oldest health and social care charity, established in 1833 in response to a cholera epidemic and the cotton famine. With more than 90 staff providing expertise and support for carers, advocacy and therapy services across Greater Manchester. Empowering people and enhancing lives through high-quality, person-centred approaches.

Charity turnover: more than £2.5 million

Where the charity operates: Greater Manchester (North West)

Lynne is a ‘live leader’ who understands the context of work in voluntary, community and social enterprise (VCSE) sector. She recognises leading in small organisations is one of the most difficult jobs. Her managerial and leadership experience is diverse across the VCSE, social care, NHS and private sectors.

Lynne works in the VCSE sector and at Gaddum because she wants to be part of a social movement for change as she is passionate about helping support local people in their communities through difficult times in their lives. ‘Before you are a leader, success is all about growing yourself. When you become a leader, success is all about growing others.’ In these difficult times VCSE leaders need support more than ever.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; strategic influencing; relational development; board strategy and development.

Trust Links is a mental health and wellbeing charity in South Essex. It has 50 staff, £1 million turnover and has been going for 20 years. It runs therapeutic community gardens, a wellbeing hub, a recovery college, and children and youth provision. The charity works with people with mental health issues, people with learning disabilities, children, youth and families.

Charity turnover: more than £1 million

Where the charity operates: East of England

Matt has been Chief Executive of Trust Links for 10 years, and has grown the charity from £100,000 to £1 million turnover and manages more than 50 staff. Matt has secured major contracts and multi-year funding. He was previously a commissioner in the areas of substance misuse and children's services, and a senior manager in local authorities. He has also worked in and been a trustee for small local and national charities.

Matt has an empowering, collaborative and strategic approach to leadership. The role of a charity chief exectuive can be very isolating, as they have to carefully manage relationships with boards, staff, partners and funders, continually spinning multiple plates. Through the Cascading Leadership programme, he aims to help others understand and navigate this role.

Areas of work: relational development; strategic influencing; change management; organisational development.

EVA Women's Aid offers a range of specialist services to victims of domestic abuse and sexual violence. It is an independent charity with 25 staff and 19 volunteers.

Charity turnover: £500,000–1 million

Where the charity operates: North East

Before joining the voluntary and community sector, Richinda was a probation officer for 13 years and has 30 years’ experience working in local authorities in a range of roles including management. Richinda achieved the CMI Level 5 Management and Leadership qualification and is experienced in change management, and organisational development with a particular interest in team dynamics.

‘I love my job. This is without doubt the best job I have ever had.’ Richinda is strongly drawn to the voluntary and community sector and feels comfortable as a leader within it. She likes to do things differently, and believes that you won’t make a difference by being the same as everyone else.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; board strategy and development; relational development.

Reeltime Music exists to bring about a positive change in the lives of disadvantaged young people, through creative workshops and projects enabling young people to break down barriers, learn new skills, increase aspirations and develop a more active lifestyle. Since 1997, more than 20,000 young people have benefited from tailored support and self-directed projects. Eleven staff and ten volunteers deliver regular weekly group sessions, which build personal and creative skills in young people facing a range of barriers.

Charity turnover: £250–500,000

Where the charity operates: Scotland

Ryan has more than 20 years’ experience of working in the voluntary and community sector. He has served as a trustee on the board of North Lanarkshire’s Third Sector Interface for the past ten years. He is also a fellow of the Clore Social Leadership Experienced Leader programme. Ryan holds a first-class honours degree from the Open University.

Ryan believes in empowering people to show up as the leaders they want to be by bringing out the wisdom and insight they already possess. Specific support areas include board relationships, developing organisational culture, leadership development (including chief executive development), funding strategy, general management and workload management.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; board strategy and development.

field_job_title.value: Chief Executive, Interlink RCT (county voluntary council for Rhondda Cynon Taf)

body.value:
Interlink RCT is a members-led charity focused on creating connected, resourceful and sustainable communities, where people develop trust, respect and understanding, have good health and can access the resources they need.

Interlink RCT supports individuals, communities and organisations to work together to have a positive impact on people’s lives. Interlink RCT believes stronger communities result from building on their existing assets and strengths, empowering individuals, communities and organisations to have an equal voice and to make a difference through community development. 

Charity turnover: more than £1 million

Where the charity operates: Wales

Simon has a breadth of experience covering community development, strategic planning, developing consortia, coaching managers, board development and working with strategic partners. This includes working with community anchor organisations to embed community connector (social prescribing) roles. He enjoys working one to one to support people to develop their critical thinking to overcome challenges.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; strategic influencing; relational development; and board strategy and development.

Disability North is a user-led charity based in Newcastle upon Tyne promoting inclusion, independence and choice to disabled people throughout the north of England. Disability North supports thousands of disabled people every year across the north of England by providing the right advice and support on issues of health and social welfare relating to any aspect of disability.

Charity turnover: £500,000–1 million

Where the charity operates: North East

Victoria has been a chief executive for more than 5 years and has 15 years’ senior leadership, research and consultancy experience. At Disability North she provides leadership and ensures the aims and objectives of the organisation are met. This includes overseeing the day-to-day operations of the charity along with being responsible for developing and delivering Disability North’s long-term strategy.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; strategic influencing.

No Limits is a youth information, advice, counselling and support service for children and young people aged under 26 years. With 120 members of staff and more than 100 volunteers, it supports approximately 7,000 young people a year across Hampshire, working in partnership with statutory and voluntary agencies.

Charity turnover: more than £1 million

Where the charity operates: South East

Annabel was Chief Executive of No Limits South for 24 years, before stepping down in 2020, and she now undertakes part-time development work, assesses learners, and undertakes training and fundraising for No Limits South. She also carries out children's home inspections for Ofsted. While Annabel was at No Limits South, it developed from a small charity to one with a budget of £3.2 million per year.

A firm believer that the voluntary sector can influence and lead innovation supporting young people, and letting their voice be heard, Annabel can support voluntary sector leaders to grow their sphere of influence and their organisations, develop partnerships within the statutory and voluntary sector and work effectively with boards.

Areas of work: board strategy and development; relational development; strategic influencing; change management; organisational development.

Phase Trust has been working alongside children and young people for more than 20 years, having an impact on 3–4,000 lives each year. The majority of Phase Trust’s activities are aimed at young people aged 7–24, most of whom have social, emotional and behavioural challenges. The charity works with young people who have experienced exploitation, supports young people with mental health and wellbeing issues, and offers young people personal development.

Charity turnover: £250–500,000

Where the charity operates: West Midlands

Jayne has been Chief Executive of Phase Trust for 17 years, growing the organisation from one that focused on grassroots delivery to an organisation with regional impact. Jayne is part of several key strategic forums and steering groups that work on the emotional health, exploitation and neglect agendas. She is also an accredited trainer, delivering training nationally on topics including exploitation and serious youth violence, adolescent neglect, exploitation and child sexual abuse.

Jayne can offer support using a relational leadership approach. Jayne strongly believes that passion is caught not taught and that the Cascading Leadership programme can encourage and empower leaders to deliver local services best serving their local communities needs.

Areas of work: change management; strategic influencing; organisational development.

field_job_title.value: Chief Executive, St John's Hospice, North Lancashire and South Lakes

body.value:
St John’s Hospice covers a population of 260,000 in North Lancashire and South Cumbria. The area has some of the most-affluent and most-deprived areas in England. The hospice provides end-of-life care and bereavement services to people aged over 18 with any life-shortening condition. It has an ‘outstanding’ CQC rating.

Charity turnover: more than £1 million

Where the charity operates: North West

This is Sue’s second role in a hospice and, both times, she has been recruited to sort out a mess. ‘I’m good in a crisis – I’m resilient, motivated and motivating.’ Many of the issues she has faced have been due to poor board leadership, and sorting this was vital. Having led both charities from deficit to surplus, Sue knows a focus on purpose is the key to success.

Sue has worked for national charities but always felt too far away from the cause; working in a hospice means she has the joy of speaking to patients and families and that really matters to her. ‘I’m motivated by seeing teams learn and grow, by working hard and by being a responsible leader.’ She thinks the position of a leader in a hierarchy should be worn with humility.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; strategic influencing; relational development; board strategy and development.

Annie works in the Leadership and Organisational Development team, where she is responsible for the operational and business function. She works alongside the senior leadership team in strategic, operational and resource planning. She leads on annual budget setting, financial forecasting and reporting on performance/KPIs and risk and is a member of the management team.

Annie has more than 15 years' experience in the charity sector; before joining The King's Fund she worked at a retirement estate with responsibility for its social aspects, focusing on initiatives to strengthen and improve independent living for its residents.

Johnson has left the Fund. 

Yan Ning (or Johnson as he prefers to be called), is a senior ophthalmology registrar, training to become a consultant eye surgeon. He currently works across sites at Western Eye Hospital, Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust and Moorfields Eye Hospital. Johnson is passionate about population health and ways to overcome inequality access to health care. He is particularly interested in preventable causes of visual impairment and health promotion. His research on whole population visual screening during his academic foundation years has influenced how childhood visual screening is conducted in England. 

Johnson has a strong track record in leading quality improvement projects that have improved patient care locally and regionally. He was awarded the coveted Health Education England KSS School of Ophthalmology Leadership Prize for four consecutive years. He is a board-certified fellow of the Royal College of Ophthalmologists, European Board of Ophthalmologists and Higher Education Academy UK. He is currently The King’s Fund and Health Education England National Population Health Fellow.

Ian leads the Information Technology (IT) team and services at the Fund. He provides the strategic and operational leadership in respect of the Fund’s use of technology and associated services.

Ian has worked for 20 years leading teams to deliver IT change and transformation within charity, government and corporate hospitality sector organisations. He joined the Fund in 2021 having previously worked at Tate Galleries.

Jeremy joined the Leadership and Organisational Development team in 2021 to support leaders across health and care facing the challenges of complexity and integration to create more effective, efficient and person-centred ways of getting things done. His practice is anchored in the combination of complexity-friendly and psychologically informed approaches to service design, leadership and change.

Jeremy holds a BSc in mechanical engineering and began his career in manufacturing. After gaining an MBA, he has accrued more than 25 years’ experience in international, multi-sector consulting and senior leadership roles, including a spell as Director of Quality Improvement at the Care Quality Commission. He has co-designed and taught several Masters programmes applying systems thinking in service organisations and is currently a Visiting Fellow at Newcastle Business School, contributing to its academic and practical work on human learning systems.

Cara is Press and Public Affairs Manager at The King’s Fund. She is responsible for overseeing the Fund’s stakeholder and parliamentary engagement work and for securing media coverage to support the Fund’s strategic priorities. Cara also manages the stakeholder breakfast events.

Prior to working at the Fund, Cara was External Affairs Manager at The Resolution Foundation and before that she worked for two Members of Parliament in their Westminster offices.

Cara is also a qualified yoga teacher and has previously taught pregnancy and postnatal yoga.

Annalisa Jenkins, MBBS, FRCP, is a biopharma thought leader with more than 25 years’ industry experience. She has extensive experience in building and financing biotech companies pursuing cures for challenging rare diseases. She has built and led teams advancing programmes from scientific research through clinical development, regulatory approval, and into health care systems globally. She is an advocate for diversity and inclusion, particularly for women in science.

Annalisa has served as President and Chief Executive of Dimension Therapeutics and other leadership roles have included senior positions at Merck Serono and at Bristol Myers-Squibb. Earlier in her career, Annalisa was a medical officer in the British Royal Navy.

She is a board member of several growing companies, including Oncimmune, AVROBIO, COMPASS Pathways, AOBiome, AgeX; a medical trustee for the British Heart Foundation; a committee member of the Science Board to the US Food and Drug Administration; advisory board member at FasterCures; and Chair of Court at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine.

Kamila Hawthorne has been a GP in South Wales for 26 years, She is also Head of the graduate-entry medicine programme at Swansea University and a trustee of the Royal College of General Practitioners. She is also a Bevan Commissioner. Kamila originally qualified from Oxford University in 1984 and completed her GP training in Nottingham in 1988.

Kamila has a deep interest in the social accountability of medical schools, and believes that we should be training excellent, caring and inclusive clinicians, for a global society. She is passionate about the role of GPs in patient care and as advocates for patients.

Her research and clinical working interests have been in health inequalities and access to health services. With wide experience of general practice and running community projects in diabetes and heart disease, she has been named ‘GP of the Year’ twice and was awarded an MBE in the Queen’s New Year Honours List 2017 for services to general practice.

Alan has 40 years’ experience in international investment management, having led two investment businesses in the UK and US. His most recent full-time position was as a main board director and Chief Investment Officer of Schroders. Before that he was Group Chief Investment Officer and Vice-Chairman of State Street Global Advisors, and Executive Vice-President of State Street Corporation. He has been awarded ‘Chief Investment Officer of the Year’ on three occasions.

Alan is Chairman of Artemis and serves as a trustee or adviser to a number of charitable and commercial organisations. Until recently, Alan was a governor of the Wellcome Trust and Chair of its Investment Committee. He also served as Chairman of CDP, a climate change non-governmental organisation.

Alan has a BA and MA in natural science (physics) from Cambridge.

Richard Clark is a commissioner of the Royal Hospital Chelsea and Non-Executive Chair of the College of Legal Practice.

Richard was formerly Executive Managing Partner of Slaughter and May and Head of Dispute Resolution. He is a leading dispute resolution lawyer with more than 30 years’ experience in legal practice.  He is also a commercial mediator.

Richard is a trustee of the Thrombosis Research Trust and a non-executive director of MGC. He is also an honorary fellow of Harris Manchester College, Oxford, and a member of the Commercial Law Centre at the University of Oxford. He has formerly held trustee roles at the University of Falmouth and Tate St Ives.

Dr Stephanie Kuku is a health technology director, a senior consultant at Hardian Health and a senior adviser and consultant at the World Health Organization’s Department of Digital Health and Innovation.

She completed her medical degree at University of Bristol, and was awarded a doctorate in clinical research (oncology) from University College London, where she remains an honorary senior research fellow at the Institute of Women's Health. Stephanie is the Healthcare Lead for Women in AI and is a co-investigator on the NHSX' NHS AI Lab Artificial Intelligence and Racial and Ethnic Inequalities in Health and Care project.

She sits on the advisory boards of Spex Capital, London, and the Special Situations Fund, New York.

During her clinical career she sat on the council of the British Gynaecological Cancer Society and was awarded international travelling fellowships from the Memorial Sloane Kettering Cancer Centre, US; Cancer Hospital Pernambuco, Brazil; and Centre du Cancer Oscar Lambret, France.

Saoni works in the Leadership and Organisational Development team as a programme co-ordinator, working on a variety of The King’s Fund’s open programmes, commissioned pieces of work and other projects.

Before joining the Fund, Saoni worked for seven years as the deputy director of residential summer schools for Churchill House School of English Language, operationally managing nine summer schools, staff, and stakeholders, and running improvement projects. Before this she was an administrator and TEFL (Teaching English as a Foreign Language) teacher.

Jordan joined The King’s Fund in November 2021 as a Marketing Executive. She sits within the central marketing  team and her work involves implementing the Fund’s marketing strategy, establishing cohesive plans to develop products and promote the Fund’s open programmes, events, consultancy services and commissioned work.

Jordan previously worked at Londonwide Local Medical Committee, the representative body for more than 7,000 GPs and nearly 1,200 practices in London. While working there she managed the organisation’s multiple social media channels, organised press enquiries and collaborated with respected health care publications including Healthcare Leader and Pulse. She has a degree in History from Coventry University.

Nicola is a researcher in the policy team. Her main areas of interest include tackling health inequalities and bringing the voices and experiences of patients, carers and the public into the policy arena.

Nicola joins The King’s Fund from North East London NHS Foundation Trust where she practiced as a social worker in a community mental health team. Here, she supported the delivery of a clinical trial for a new way of working in mental health services, peer-supported open dialogue, and led engagement with practitioners and the public as part of the transformation of community mental health services. Before this, Nicola was a research lead at BritainThinks. Particular highlights include leading an ethnographic research project exploring experiences of fuel poverty and deliberative research with members of the public on topics ranging from the design and use of parks and green spaces to water resources management planning.

Caroline Murphy works in the digital team and is currently responsible for developing the approach to the Fund’s email marketing platform.

Before joining the Fund in December 2021, Caroline worked at the Royal College of Nursing, working on their social media and email communication across multiple campaigns. Before that, Caroline spent time working within local government communications and the publishing industry, having completed a Masters in Publishing in 2015.

Dana was the first ever Head of Diversity and Inclusion at The King’s Fund. She joined the Fund in 2021 during the pandemic and left the Fund in December 2022.

Her role was to make sure that the entire team at The King’s Fund are heard, feel valued for the differences they bring, and are able to feel that they belong and that they can succeed and thrive. 

A native Trinidadian, Dana has now lived in the UK for over 15 years. She has spent the entirety of her career helping organisations to build diverse brands and workforces that are representative of the wider world around us, while shaping inclusive cultures where people want to stick around. Dana is also a trained and certified mediator, coach practitioner and certified Mental Health First Aider.

Loreen joined The King’s Fund in 2022 as a research assistant in the policy directorate, and she became a researcher in October 2022. Her interests lie in how intersectional approaches are employed in implementing policies and addressing health inequalities. She is also interested in how voices of marginalised communities can be brought to the fore of social policy and practice, with a focus on using research methods that are inclusive.

Loreen is an academic who has taught in social science disciplines of sociology and psychology over the past 10 years. She has also worked with various statutory and voluntary, community and faith organisations on addressing inequalities in policy and practice.

Charlie’s role within the Fund is to provide the best possible environment and experience for all stakeholders as well as ensuring the building’s long-term financial value and profitability by delivering best-in-class facilities services.

Charlie has held facilities roles across many sectors but most recently worked as an account manager at a flexible-workspace provider where he delivered facilities services to various public and private sector clients within London and the home counties.

LGBT Foundation is one of the UK's leading lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans (LGBT) community charities, believing in a fair and equal society where all lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans people can achieve their full potential. The LGBT Foundation provides health, wellbeing and other services directly to LGBT people and supports a wide range of organisations which work with LGBT people.

Charity turnover: more than £1 million

Where the charity operates: across the UK

Rob is passionate about the principles and practice of the Cascading Leadership programme, particularly in the context of Covid-19 recovery, as it helps reduce isolation and simplify the daily complexities encountered by VCS leaders. Rob believes that organisations are only as good as the people who work in them. He wants to support the growth and sustainability of the sector, and nurture individuals’ skills and talents.

During his time at LGBT Foundation, Rob has been on a secondment to the Greater Manchester Health and Social Care Partnership, working with a plethora of system leaders to re-imagine HIV prevention and support services, helping to foster and facilitate new shared solutions. He was able to encourage commissioners to think and reflect on the ways in which they can further support the local VCS.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; relational development.

Andy works as a senior visiting fellow at The King’s Fund. He works on general practice policy, and is also a practising GP.

Before joining The King’s Fund, Andy worked as a senior policy adviser in the system transformation team at NHS England. He has spent more than 20 years working in health care in Frimley, most recently as the accountable officer for Frimley Clinical Commissioning Group. Andy has achieved ‘outstanding’ ratings in both commissioner and provider organisations. He has overseen the development of innovative solutions for care, and financial and governance arrangements between health care services, local government, public health, social care and the voluntary sector.

Andy has postgraduate qualifications in child health, surgery, and general practice. He is a senior fellow of the Faculty of Medical Leadership and Management and was previously a GP trainer.

Carolyn is a Professor at the Birmingham Leadership Institute at the University of Birmingham. She was previously Chief Executive of Oldham Council and Accountable Officer for NHS Oldham Clinical Commissioning Group. She is passionate about the role public services have in improving people’s life chances and has taken forward a wide-reaching programme of service reform and integration to deliver significantly better outcomes.

Carolyn has significant public sector experience, and a long-time commitment to understanding public service delivery from different perspectives. This includes involvement in the Civil Society Future Inquiry and the Centre for Policing Research and Learning at the Open University. She has a Masters in literature from the Open University and a Masters in public administration from Warwick Business School.

Carolyn was awarded an OBE in June 2016 for her services to local government and public service reform.

Luca is a researcher in the policy team. His areas of interest include service integration and health inequalities.

Before joining The King’s Fund, Luca worked for New Local, a local government think tank and membership organisation. While working there he conducted and led research into policy challenges facing councils across a range of areas, including health and social care. Prior to that he worked at NatCen Social Research in both research and communications roles. He holds an master’s degree in public policy from King’s College London.

Sarah left the Fund in June 2023.
