Sarah sits within the central marketing team and her work involves implementing the Fund’s marketing strategy and establishing cohesive plans to develop products and promote the Fund’s open programmes, events, consultancy services and commissioned work.

Before joining the Fund Sarah worked at Coin Street, a social enterprise based on London’s South Bank that owns 13 acres of land as well as commercial units, art galleries, conference spaces, a gym, nursery and housing. All profits are reinvested back into the community and are used to fund community programmes. Her role there involved managing events marketing, social media and designing digital and print materials. She studied at the University of Manchester and has a Masters degree in Marketing.

Michael works within the events and partnerships team managing a programme of conferences and events. His role focuses on ensuring the programme is delivered to a high standard, meets the expectations of colleagues and delegates, and enhances the reputation and public profile of The King’s Fund.

Before joining the Fund, Michael was at Westminster Forum Projects for 14 years where he oversaw the management and development of the conference programme across a wide range of topics including health; food, farming and nutrition; energy, environment and transport; social policy; media; and telecoms. He also launched the Forum’s conference arm in Scotland and was involved in its work in Wales and London.

Gemma joined Blood Cancer UK as Chief Executive in September 2017 and has led the organisation through an ambitious transformation programme. She has had a varied career working across the charity, higher education and health sectors, most recently at King’s College London and King’s Health Partners as Executive Director of Fundraising and Supporter Development where she conceived and led the ‘World questions | King’s answers’ campaign, which raised more than £610 million and changed the lives of people around the world. She spent seven years as a trustee at ActionAid UK and joined the board of Blood Cancer UK in May 2020.

Emily left the Fund in January 2023.

Emily works in the events and partnerships team and is responsible for leading both virtual and in-person events at The King’s Fund.

Before joining the Fund in January 2022, Emily spent three years working at Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) where she managed the internal events, ranging from conferences to gala dinners. Emily has a first-class business degree from the University of Kent, where she focused on marketing. While studying, she supported local charities by creating marketing materials for their events.

field_job_title.value: Chief Executive, Advice Support Knowledge Information (ASKI)

body.value:
ASKI delivers services that are responsive and preventive and have transformed the lives of thousands of people across Croydon each year. As a user-led organisation, ASKI operates an open-house policy for its open social programmes, and a drop-in community café, which provides a range of interactive services with dedicated volunteers, staff and service users.

Charity turnover: up to £250,000

Where the charity operates: Greater London

Joseph is a Black leader with more than 25 years’ experience in the third sector supporting the least privileged communities in a variety of settings and in work areas, including health and wellbeing, housing, drugs/alcohol misuse, young people, older people and intergenerational work. Joseph wants to see an increase of Black senior leaders in the health care sector. Based on his experience with Cascading Leadership, Joseph knows how the programme can be transformational for both the individual and the organisation. Joseph has a unique blend of experience, perspective and background that would provide more diverse support to leaders of smaller charities, wishing to develop themselves and the organisations they work for.

Joseph believes in a leadership style that is supportive and open, where leaders can be offered a safe and confidential space that encourages strategic and critical thinking and promotes conversations that can examine and change how leaders operate. This coaching support approach can help with understanding issues (such as unconscious bias) and achieving leadership goals.

Areas of work: organisational development; change management; strategic influencing; relational development; board strategy and development.

Gabrielle Mathews was on placement in the leadership and organisational development team, contributing to the development of the Leadership and Workforce Summit and FutureLearn courses run by The King’s Fund and considering how we can support aspiring clinical leaders. She has an interest in quality improvement and co-production with expertise in working with children and young people.

She has a background in advocating for greater recognition of children and young people’s health in policy and has recently qualified as a doctor from Imperial College London, where she also completed a bachelor’s degree in Global Health. Alongside this work she is the youngest member of the NHS Assembly, advising the board of NHS England on their implementation of the Long Term Plan. She has significant experience working to improve the lives of children and young people, working as an oversight board member of the REAL Centre at the Health Foundation, member of the #iwill partnership board, part of theBackYouthAlliance and as a trustee of Imperial College Union.

Bill Morgan was a visiting fellow at The King's Fund between May and October 2022. He has a particular interest in examining political obstacles to NHS transformation and worked on a project for The King’s Fund and Engage Britain examining workforce policy and planning.

Bill was formerly the Conservative Party’s health adviser in the mid-2000s, and a special adviser at the Department of Health in the early 2010s. A successful entrepreneur, he co-founded and co-led one of the country’s largest health communications consultancies – Incisive Health.

Ravi was appointed as a Visiting Fellow at The King’s Fund in August 2022. He is currently working with the Fund on a project to develop a ten-year strategy for pharmacy in the NHS in England. 

Ravi will be working closely with the government, NHS bodies and other key stakeholders as part of his efforts to integrate and transform the future of pharmacy practice to support improvement of care, access, outcomes and value within the reforming NHS in England.

A pharmacist prescriber by background, Ravi has worked in general practice for more than 10 years. He has held several national and advisory positions across Department of Health and Social Care, NHS England and NHS Improvement, the British Medical Association, Royal College of General Practitioners, and the Royal Pharmaceutical Society. 

He is an Adjunct Professor at University of Canberra in Australia, Fellow of the Royal Pharmaceutical Society and a member of the NHS Assembly, an advisory group supporting the implementation of the NHS Long Term Plan.

Saoirse Mallorie is a Senior Analyst in the policy team, and conducts quantitative analysis across the health and social care landscape.

Before joining the Fund, Saoirse worked at the Treasury as a Distributional Analyst, modelling the impact on households of various government policies, including the recent change to adult social care funding. She has also worked at Universities UK and the Cabinet Office, and studied Cambridge University and the London School of Economics.

Manishta Sunnia (xe/xem) is a freelance writer, researcher and facilitator. Manishta holds a MA in Gender and Sexuality from SOAS, University of London. Manishta has previously worked for the National Union of Students, People and Planet and with Deaf and disabled people’s organisations such as Inclusion London & Sisters of Frida.

field_job_title.value: Senior Research Analyst,  the Centre for Progressive Policy

body.value: Rosie joined the Centre for Progressive Policy (CPP) in 2019 as a Senior Research Analyst and manages their research programme. She has written on the importance of long term investment in public services and the role of business in making the economy more inclusive, including through good jobs. Before CPP, Rosie worked as a Senior Economist in the Cabinet Office, supporting Brexit preparations. She has also held several other government positions, including in the international group at HM Treasury.

field_job_title.value: Director of Research and Policy, the Centre for Progressive Policy

body.value: Ben is Director of Research and Policy at the Centre for Progressive Policy and leads the development of the Centre’s original research programme. Most recently, Ben was Assistant Director of Research and Policy at the International Longevity Centre, exploring the economic implications of demographic change. Before this, Ben undertook economic analysis for the Financial Conduct Authority, and has also worked in research and policy for the Chartered Insurance Institute and HM Treasury.

Nicole Moore works in external affairs function within the communications directorate, and plays a key role in the media and stakeholder activities of The King’s Fund.

Before joining the Fund in 2022, Nicole spent four years at NHS Providers, the membership organisation representing NHS hospitals, mental health, community and ambulance services. As media relations manager, she played a key role in the delivery of the media strategy and was communications lead for various policy portfolios, including NHS performance, mental health and social care. Nicole has also worked in local government and has a degree in public relations and advertising.

Beth is a currently a Policy & Strategy trainee on the NHS Graduate Management Training Scheme and is working at the Fund for the duration of her two month ‘flexi’ placement within the Policy team. She has joined from a placement as a Project Manager in the Private Office of the National Director of Primary Care and Community Services at NHS England, following on from her first placement in NHS England’s Personalised Care Group working on data strategy and analysis. 

Before starting the GMTS, Beth graduated from Durham University with an integrated Masters in Biological Sciences and worked at the Human Fertilisation & Embryology Authority and managed requests for information from donors, donor-conceived individuals and their parents. She is currently studying part-time for a Postgraduate Diploma in Health Policy at Imperial College London and has just completed a Postgraduate Certificate in Healthcare Leadership at the University of Birmingham.

Kelly Ameneshoa is an Emergency Medicine Doctor working across South London and Surrey, in the later stages of her training to be a Consultant in Emergency Medicine. 

Having worked in emergency departments across the country, Kelly was particularly struck by the wide health inequalities present across the population and became interested in practical actions that she as a doctor could take through her role to tackling this. Kelly is particularly interested in improving children and young people’s mental and physical health. 
 
Kelly has led quality improvement projects aiming to improve the care of young people in the emergency department; to streamline referrals to mental health services; and to improve the end-of-life care planning for patients with end stage liver failure. Kelly has worked internationally for several non-governmental organisations. 
 
From August 2022, Kelly joins us as The King’s Fund and Health Education England National Population Health Fellow for one year.

field_job_title.value: Head of Policy at Disability Rights UK

body.value: Fazilet Hadi is Head of Policy at Disability Rights UK. She is also a Non-Executive Director at Cambridgeshire Community Services NHS Trust. Fazilet started her career as a solicitor in Law Centres and then worked in senior equality roles in Local Government. Fazilet was a director at RNIB (Royal National Institute of Blind People) and stepped down as Deputy Chief Executive in 2018.

Toby joined The King’s Fund in 2022 to lead the responsive policy team, which aims to influence decision-makers to improve health and care for everyone in England.  

Toby has 15 years’ policy and communications experience spanning government, the voluntary, community and social enterprise sector, and the private sector. Before joining the Fund, he worked at the Department of Health and Social Care and led the team that prepared the health and care system for Brexit and helped mitigate risks relating to issues such as Northern Ireland’s medicine supply and the impact on public health of fewer border controls.  

Toby also spent five years leading the public affairs team at Citizens Advice, which included working with the government to secure £1.5 billion to improve the Universal Credit benefits system. He has also worked for Labour and Conservative health and business ministers, a health care communications agency and volunteered on President Obama’s 2012 election campaign.

Shelly Hossain has been the Director of Global Learning Consultancy for the past 25 years. She has expertise in executive coaching, professional leadership development and workshop facilitation skills.  As well as her work in organisational development she also has experience in management consulting and cultural change in her current and previous roles.

Cindy Cox is an independent consultant with more than 15 years’ experience in management organisational development (OD). She is an OD consultant and coach with particular interests in how OD and virtual facilitation connect. 

Cindy was previously a senior consultant at the Roffey Park Institute where she achieved a Masters in people and organisational development. Her role included leading on the design and delivery of tailored OD and leadership development programmes.

Paul works in the Commercial Affairs team and is responsible for managing The King’s Fund’s premises at 11–13 Cavendish Square, including building services, facilities support and front of house, health, safety and sustainability along with capital replacement and refurbishment projects.    

Paul has worked in the facilities management industry for more than 25 years and has latterly focused on procurement, sustainability and building relocation projects. He joined the Fund in 2022 having previously worked at the Commonwealth Secretariat.

Miranda works in the HR team at The King’s Fund and is responsible for organisational development, leadership and management development and learning. She is interested in cultural and wider transformational change.

Before joining the Fund in 2022, Miranda spent 12 years in the Civil Service. She has a background in organisational design and development, learning and development, employment policy and HR.

George Newell is a programme co-ordinator in the Leadership and Organisational Development team. He supports the team in delivering a range of open programmes, and other commissioned work both virtually and face-to-face.

Before joining the Fund in 2023, George spent the early part of his career working at a health and wellness consultancy where he supported global pharmaceutical and health care clients with their digital strategy and performance marketing campaigns. He has a Masters in science and technology policy and a BSc in biological sciences.

field_job_title.value: Associate Director of strategic work programmes, Hampshire and Isle of Wight Integrated Care System

body.value: Jackie is an experienced senior leader and has enjoyed a varied career across the health and care sector, working in the NHS, the Department of Health, a GP Federation, as well as provider and commissioning organisations. As a former trustee of a care and support charity, Jackie is passionate about the importance of a safe and secure home in addressing health inequalities and championing collaborative solutions that can enable people to flourish.

field_job_title.value: Chief Marketing Officer and head of ESG, Civica

body.value:
As Chief Marketing Officer, Luella is responsible for the development and operation of group marketing and communications activities globally and is Head of Environmental Social Governance (ESG). Building on Civica’s strong market position and product portfolio, she is leading our brand strategy and advancing our programmes for market engagement and advocacy, responding to new market opportunities to deliver better outcomes and enhanced value for all stakeholders through our clear strategy. 

Luella was previously global head of marketing and an internal board member for financial data specialist Acuris (previously Mergermarket Group) and prior to this managed marketing for key customer groups and markets at LexisNexis.

Aisha is a programme co-ordinator in the leadership and organisational development team. She provides support to the team for a range of open programmes and other commissioned work. 

Before joining the Fund in 2023, Aisha worked in the humanitarian sector co-ordinating emergency response projects in the UK and Europe alongside an orphan-sponsorship programme. Before this she worked in the pharmaceutical sector co-ordinating phase-3 clinical trials for treatments for Alzheimer’s disease. Aisha has worked in the corporate, public and charity sectors. 

Aisha has a BSc in biomedical sciences.

Jessica works in the responsive policy team, which works to influence decision-makers to improve health and care for everyone in England. 

Before joining the Fund in 2023, Jessica worked as a policy adviser at the Royal College of Nursing, where she led on nursing workforce policy, developing positions and recommendations on nursing recruitment and retention in England. She also held a policy and public affairs role at Stonewall where she focused on building political relationships and influencing decision-makers. She spent two years working for an MP, after originally starting her career as a mental health nurse. She holds a nursing degree and an MSc in political sociology from The London School of Economics and Political Science.

Kayalveli Sivakanthan (pronounced Ky-ver-lee) works in the leadership and organisational development team at The King’s Fund. She has an interest in health, equity and inclusion. She supports the team to deliver a range of open programmes, and other commissioned work both in person and virtually. She brings an inclusive lens to all the work she does.

Before joining the Fund, Kayalveli spent four years working in a fast-paced, growing diversity and inclusion start-up where she led the transition from in-person workshops to virtual programming, during the Covid-19 pandemic. Here she upskilled herself in project management by gaining her Agile PM qualifications. She also has experience working in the charity sector and holds a BSc in psychology from Brunel University London.

Anne-Marie works in the leadership and organisational development team. She is a strategic and transformational leadership development and organisation development practitioner with a wide experience of working in the NHS at national and regional level. She is interested in systems leadership, and how people connect and lead beyond authority. She has a passion for inclusive leadership development. She has been facilitating on the White Allies programme and is an advocate for anti-racist leadership. 

Before joining the Fund, Anne-Marie spent eight years as the director of the NHS Leadership Academy in London, before running her own development practice. She is an active white ally in her ambassador role with the Different Women Movement and is a member of the national NHS Health and Care Women Leaders Network guiding group. 

Anne-Marie is a qualified coach and has a postgraduate certificate in organisational change management.

Meg is a prolific speaker and campaigner for mental health and passionate about making the health and social care system more personal, from the inside. She works with Shared Lives Plus as an Ambassador and in 2019, she won the Shared Lives Plus award for human rights.

Her nomination describes her as ‘devastatingly authentic… she inspired us to respond not as a service to a user, but as humans to a human.’ After four years in a hospital environment, Meg now lives independently with Flower, her dog, and continues to receive some day support via Shared Lives.

Ewan is Chief Executive at Shared Lives Plus, the UK Charity which represents the shared living sector, and is Deputy Director for Policy Embedding at IMPACT (Improving Adult Care Together), the UK centre for implementing evidence in adult social care.

Before joining Shared Lives Plus, he was Deputy Chief Executive at the Social Care Institute for Excellence (SCIE), a charity that identifies and promotes good practice in adults and children’s social care.

Daisy works in the leadership and organisational development team. She co-ordinates open programmes, commissioned work and supports on projects in the L&OD department. Daisy initially joined The King’s Fund to help with the administrative process of shortlisting for the GSK IMPACT awards.

Before joining the Fund in 2022, Daisy studies for an MSC in occupational psychology, and worked part-time for Bromley GP Alliance. Daisy is particularly interested in job design and employee wellbeing, and enjoys working alongside senior consultants who specialise in this field.

Rowan works in the external affairs team at The King’s Fund. She has more than 20 years’ experience working in PR and communications. 
Before joining The King’s Fund in 2022, Rowan worked at UCL for eight years leading its media work for education and health research. She also helped to set up and run its media relations training programme.

Rowan is a trained journalist and spent more than five years working on The Observer newsdesk. She has also worked for a number of charities including WWF-UK and The Associated Board of the Royal Schools of Music. She has a degree in French and Italian, is a trained English as a foreign language teacher and is a governor at her local school.

field_job_title.value: Brexit Programme Lead at the Nuffield Trust

body.value:
Mark Dayan is Brexit Programme Lead at the Nuffield Trust, working on the implications of leaving the European Union and of trade agreements for the NHS, life sciences and social care. His publications include How will Brexit affect the UK's response to coronavirus?  and Getting a Brexit deal that works for the NHS. Mark has also published work on health care in Scotland and Northern Ireland, and on legislation. He leads the Nuffield Trust's engagement with political stakeholders as Head of Public Affairs.

Mark has also assisted in research projects and external commissions. Within the Communications team, Mark works to connect our findings and expertise to our audiences through media, monitoring, and building relationships with other key stakeholders. Before joining the Trust, Mark gained experience in policy roles for the New Local Government Network and the Scottish Civil Service. He is a graduate of the University of Oxford and has an MSc in Philosophy and Public Policy from the London School of Economics.

Mark is a non-active member of the Labour Party.

Riogan works in the partnerships and business development team, providing support in the planning and delivery of the corporate partner and supporter programme, with additional focus on exhibition and sponsor liaison, and speaker administration. The business development side of her role centres on support with tender compliance.

Before joining the Fund in March 2023, Riogan worked in operations at a production company, focusing on events, legal support and administration, and office management. Riogan has a BA in politics, sociology and east European studies from UCL.

Hannah is part of the digital team at The King’s Fund where she works on content for the Fund’s website, and social media and email channels. In her role she also supports the launch of events and courses across the digital channels, as well as working on website development projects.  

Before joining The King’s Fund in spring 2023, Hannah worked at LloydsPharmacy Online Doctor where she created and published website content. In her role she also supported the search engine optimisation (SEO) and social media strategies. Before this she worked in digital copywriting and editing in the travel sector.

Alex leads on diversity and inclusion (D&I) at The King’s Fund. While many initiatives are driven by our staff, Alex is responsible for setting the D&I strategy, fostering a more inclusive workforce for everyone, and ensuring that our staff networks are supported. 

Alex was previously People Strategy and Communications Lead at Citigroup, and more recently Head of Programs at equality, diversity and inclusion consultancy and tech company WERKIN, which provides career and leadership development programmes for organisations such as Meta, Google, and the NHS.  

Alex’s three years of experience working in NHS trusts, integrated care systems and NHS England has given her insight into the experience of under-represented clinical staff and leaders in health and care. 

Alex is also a classically trained actress and co-founder of House of Pride, a platform for queer women and non-binary people.

Peter Hay is a former president of the Association of Directors for Adult Social Care (ADASS), Chair of Turning Point and the Social Work Awards and a board member for Anchor, GoodGym and Longhurst Housing.

Louise Ansari is the Chief Executive at Healthwatch England. Prior to this, Louise was Director of Communications and Influencing at the Centre for Ageing Better, and has a strong background in communications and engagement. Louise’s roles span across local and national government, health bodies and charities including social policy and local services. She is passionate about ensuring the public voice makes a difference in shaping health and care services.

Dominique is the Programme Director for the 2023 Leadership for Population Health programme at The King’s Fund. She is also Director of Population Health at Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust and Chief Medical Officer and AHSN Deputy for UCLPartners 

Dominique has nearly 20 years’ experience as a doctor, in public health, and health care leadership and management. She has published more than 40 peer-reviewed papers, is an Associate Editor of BMJ Leader and an Honorary Senior Clinical Lecturer at Imperial College London.  

Alongside directly leading work with an impact on policy and practice, Dominique also supports leaders, organisations and systems to tackle complex challenges around improving population health, reducing inequalities and improving care so it is kinder and more equitable. 

Dominique has a Masters in public health, a Masters in business administration and a certificate in executive education. She is currently a Governor of University College Hospital and a Board Member of the Patient Revolutionin the US.

Fran works in the communications team, where they assist with media inquiries, media monitoring, event support and stakeholder data maintenance. They also support the work of the digital team.  

Before joining the Fund in 2023, Fran held several communications-related roles at Mansfield College, University of Oxford, where they were involved in producing alumni print publications, email marketing, and arranging a portfolio of events for alumni of the university.

Habib is IT Infrastructure Manager at The King’s Fund, a role that leverages his technical expertise and strategic mindset. He oversees the design, implementation, and maintenance of the Fund's IT infrastructure, ensuring a high-performing and secure network capable of supporting the organisation’s business functions. 

Habib started his career in disaster recovery and continuity co-ordination, where he honed his skills in managing unforeseen disruptions and ensuring business continuity. He has held roles in infrastructure, network security admin, and IT infrastructure and applications support, where he learnt the intricacies of maintaining robust IT infrastructure and implementing comprehensive security measures.

Naja is an organisational development consultant, supervisor and executive coach. She has extensive experience of working with senior leaders on system-wide change. Her previous clients include the Cabinet Office, the Department for Transport and Public Health England.  

Naja’s practice is anchored in building a strong client relationship and draws on complexity and whole-systems approaches. She works with clients to discover together what is going on in their system and to co-create realistic and hopeful ways forward. Her research interests include the impact of providing safe spaces for leaders to reflect on their practice.  

Before joining the Fund, Naja was a senior leader in the Cabinet Office. She has experience from international organisations, including Consumers International, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development  and the European Union. Naja holds Masters degrees in Organisational Change and in Law, diplomas in organizational development supervision and coaching, and is accredited by the Tavistock Institute to coach for senior leaders and boards.

Alistair is an experienced organisational development (OD) practitioner, having been a member of senior leadership teams in the health, education and charity sectors, and most recently in the Civil Service. 

Previously Alistair worked for Deloitte and PwC Consulting focusing on OD within the public sector, particularly in local government (social care) and health. He has also worked in the NHS supporting the creation of clinical commissioning groups, and the development of the associated clinical support units. Alistair moved from the NHS to a national charity, where he led on the development of organisational values and a review in organisational culture.  

Alistair is passionate about OD, with a particular interest and focus on dialogic OD work, organisational culture and group dynamics. He enjoys working with groups solving complex problems that require a deep understanding of relationships and self. 

Alistair holds a Masters degree in people and organisational development, is a qualified CIPFA accountant and a Fellow of CIPD.
